He knows how to butter her up, to keep her mind at ease as much as possible. He realizes that the way to get out is to treat her with respect & act like he understands her & that he's on her side. He figured what he had to do from this minute to the next, to the next. Yet he took risks, exploring the area and trying to escape. Using the type-writer as a weight to work out his shoulder and strength is smart. Sheldon is enormously witty and clever. Most victims in movies are just hopeless and stupid. The audience will feel for him because of that reason. He would have to be strong, to survive Annie Wilkes. Kathy Bates is best suited for the mercurial psychopathic role of Wilkes. Wilkes can be describe as a American yandere. Wilkes is gentle and care for a lot before their romantic devotion becomes mentally destructive in nature, often through violence and brutality. She subjects him to a series of physical and psychological tortures throughout the film. Bates makes Wilkes out to be a cunning, brutal and dangerously disturbed woman who hides her psychosis behind a cheery facade while displays obsessive-compulsive personality disorder by using with childishly strange words and phrases when expressing anger. Kathy Bates won the Academy Award for Best Actress for this role. The supporting cast is made out to be one man, local sheriff, Buster (Richard Farnsworth) whom is investigating Paul's disappearance. The character rarely gives anything to the plot and personal wasn't needed in the film: pointless. Misery is a Rob Reiner film that based on the Stephen King's 1987 novel. There are some different between the film and book. For instance, the book was more violence to Paul. In the book, when Paul mentions that her typewriter is missing a key, Annie cuts off his thumb. Rather than hobbling him, in the book, Annie cuts off his foot. Buster is also treated with more violence in his death with her riding over his body with a lawnmower. In the book, Paul become an addict to painkillers and finish writing 'Fast Cars'. In the film, Paul becomes successful with his book 'Higher Education of Phillip J. Stone'. One of Stephen King's inspirations for Misery was the reaction his fans had to The Eyes of the Dragon. The fans rejected The Eyes of the Dragon because of its lack of horror. Paul Sheldon feeling chained to the Misery books by his fans was a metaphor for his feeling chained to horror fiction. As a horror/ thriller movie it works. People still cringe during the "hobbling" scene. Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata was such a good choice as background music. The whole movie has a sense of tongue in cheek about it. Director Rob Reiner did a good job on it. The camera work is very similar to Alfred Hitchcock. Perhaps because the way King wrote the protagonist as immobilized in a wheel chair, Reiner purposely wanted to make allusions to Rear Window. Allot of the disorienting angles and suspense scenes reminded people of Psycho too. Some people might hate the ending since it different from the book. Endings are pretty hard to manage in general, because everyone kind of has their own expectations and predictions of how the story should end. It's especially difficult if you've invested a lot into the story. If it doesn't end the way you think it should have, you get disappointed. This is an intriguing notion, the craziness of fans. I suppose it echoes the surprise Annie Wilkes felt when she read that Misery was killed off. Critics are like that. A great movie that stirs the pot.

Review title: Now this is what a horror movie should be like
Review_body: I didn't really want to watch this movie as it dealt with some disturbing issues. Namely false imprisonment and a psychotic fan actively preventing her prisoner from leaving. It seemed disturbing, but I decided to watch it anyway and discovered that it was not as disturbing as I thought it would be. What this movie does say, is what I see in a lot of Stephen King movies, and the books that I read, that horror goes far beyond nasty monster and lots of gore.A famous writer, Paul Sheldon (James Caan) finishes a book and leaves his retreat in the mountains in the middle of a blizzard and ends up crashing his car. He is then pulled from the wreckage by a passing nurse (Kathy Bates) who we first discover is a fan, and then learn that she had been stalking him. He at first believes that he is there recovering, but soon he comes to realise that he is not going to get out - especially since he killed off her favourite character in one of his books.What this movie explores is the dark, unseen side of the human psyche. We consider humanity to be generally nice, and prefer to ignore our darker side. Yet it is something that we cannot avoid with stories of horrid murders by apparently innocent people. Yet once they commit such an act, we ignore what drove them to do that act and label them as being bad. What we really ignore is that we are capable of being driven to that point at well.This is not the case in Misery. The woman has been twisted for a long time. We don't get to know her that well to know what caused her to go that way, but we do know that she has been married and the man whom she was married to was disappointing. We also soon discover some nasty secrets about her past, and maybe it was that which slowly drove her mind into the state that it is in, seeking the beauty of Sheldon's books to escape the reality of her true nature.What I like about Stephen King (and what people seem to ignore regarding his works) is that he explores the human psyche, and it is this that is truly horrific, especially since it is something that we choose to ignore. Many of us will say that no human can be like that, yet we look around and see that it is not true.

Review title: A masterful well paced burn of awesomeness!
Review_body: James Caan and Kathy Bates are incredible in this spectacular Stephen King adaptation! Rob Reiner directed such unsettling experience of wild suspense, highly under talked about film. Lol makes me want soup and want to be known writer at some point. When I was a little younger I was obsessed with a bunch of Stephen King films Misery makes me want to be that way again.

Review title: So don't kill off your central character ...
Review_body: Stephen King's novel 'Misery' comes to the screen in this scary, chilling, and extremely well-acted film. James Caan has his best role for years as Paul Sheldon, celebrated author, who is rescued from a storm by his No. 1 fan Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates). All goes well until he decides to kill off his long-standing character, Misery.Annie then decides to keep him hostage until he re-writes his latest book, bringing Misery back to life. Sheldon becomes more and more under the power of his crazed fan, especially after she hobbles him, smashing his ankles so he is unable to walk and escape.This film rightly won plaudits and Oscars, and is probably the best King adaptation to make it to the screen. The two leads are excellent, there is plenty of tension, and the whole thing is worryingly believable. A warning to over-zealous writers everywhere!

Review title: Solid Adaptation, If A Bit Uneven In Tone
Review_body: As a longtime and hardcore Stephen King fan, it is hard for me to divorce my feelings for the novel from this film adaptation. But I will say this: even if you haven't read a word of King's tome, I don't believe your ranking would go any lower--only higher.For a very basic overview, "Misery" tells the story of author Paul Sheldon (James Caan), whose car slides off a snowy mountain road after finishing a book and is rescued by Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates)--his self-proclaimed "#1 fan". The problem? Annie is also crazy, meaning Sheldon is in for the fight of his life strictly to survive.As book-to-film adaptations go, this belongs on the better end of that equation. It captures the key events of the book quite well, is legitimately unsettling on a number of occasions, and the acting is fantastic (Bates especially as the loony Wilkes). Nothing boring or ho-hum to be found here. While it doesn't quite capture the author metaphors that King litters throughout his text, I won't even fault director Rob Reiner for that here, as the visceral nature of the scenario is the focus on screen.Actually, the biggest issue that kept "Misery" from jumping up another star ranking was its uneven tone at times. It seems as if the filmmakers couldn't quite decide if they wanted to make a dark comedy, or a taut psychological thriller. They basically split the difference, and sometimes that can be a bit jarring or off-putting.Overall, though, "Misery" is a solid film that deserves a solid ranking. It may not be one of my favorites of all-time or anything like that, but it certainly is a classic that I have enjoyed multiple times.

If MISERY does any one thing, it showcases a great performance by Kathy Bates. James Caan is more than adequate (he's bed-bound for the entire film, and manages to effectively convey the sheer terror of being kidnapped and kept in a "chemical straight-jacket") and Rob Reiner is at the top of his game. I caught this one when first it opened and one of the things that seemed, at that time, a bit off-putting was the almost SANITARY look of the film (the Big-Budget look and feel of the film), but I've since ascribed that to Annie's being a nurse- someone who was used to working in an antiseptic environment. Her Hobbling of Sheldon is STILL hard to watch, but it's the overall performance of Bates (a performance that's better than Robert Deniro's as Pupkin in THE KING OF COMEDY) that makes MISERY a classic Fright Film.

Review title: Clever and suspenseful psychological horror that delivers on several levels.
Review_body: Misery is a great example of an unpredictable and disturbing story set pretty much entirely in one place that is seemingly in escapable. In 1980, Stanley Kubrick delivered one of the eeriest and best horror films of all time: The Shining, penned originally by Stephen King. Ten years on, James Caan is the trapped Shelley Duvall only it's not just the snow that forbids them to leave but the fact most of the bones below his hips are severely broken. Secondly, in true gender switch fashion; the psycho is that of Annie Wilkes (Bates) who does an equally good job as that of Nicholson in The Shining.Why The Shining was a better film is because it was eerie, unpredictable and genuinely scary  it was an out and out horror as the reason to be scared was due to ghosts haunting the hotel. That said, Misery is still a great film as it uses psychology to scare the audience or if not to scare then at least make uncomfortable. Annie takes care of Paul Sheldon (Caan); a writer wanting to wrap up his recent series of successful books about a girl called Misery, with very efficient professionalism that gradually becomes efficient obsession.The reason this film stands out so well is that individual brilliant acting performances and the way in which the tension is utilised to an effective manner stick out. We, the audience, know the ending to his new book so when Annie goes on and on about how much she loves his books and the character of Misery in particular is particularly outstanding as she's not going to like the ending to his latest book  rather a 'wrapping up of events' as far as the girl of Misery is concerned. Watching Paul's reaction to each individual praise Annie gives to Misery is as excruciating as it is entertaining since we don't know how she'll react. Along with this, you have to take into account the fact that Annie is living in a wooden cabin, by her self, in the middle of nowhere which is enough evidence to suggest you have to be weary.Thankfully, the film doesn't toy around too much with this convention and lets the film flow effortlessly into the bulk of the story  Annie's further decent into madness and Paul's further decent into survival. From here, a series of events some of which are managed by cause and effect, kick in but I got the feeling Annie was the real focus  she was the most 'entertaining' character and we learn more about her than anyone else in the film. Her mental state is hinted at when they are having dinner together and a shrine is visible directly behind Paul, dedicated to Paul. The framing here is the key thing  not only are we being presented with good material in front of the camera what with a character being developed during a simple meal scene but the framing emphasises Paul's character as his head fits in perfectly with the middle of the shrine  a sign of good direction.Paul seems to try everything in the book to try and escape but there is no need to tamper with a snow cat in this film  his broken bones make for an excellent suspense device as he is limited to a wheel chair. He has to do everything in stages when he tries to escape: first there's the getting out of bed, then out of the locked room, then out of the locked front door  maybe there's another way? Oh no, I hear a car engine approaching....... so you can see that suspense and the feeling of being trapped really work well together to create an atmosphere.Misery does well in its overall delivery. The story of the old trooper trying to crack the case in true Scatman Crothers style as well as the way in which he has a look around the house alá Psycho (1960) may feel copied but it's just good suspense; a feeling of plagiarism that is partially erased by the extremely satisfying final fight scene which acts as a great payoff for the rest of the film. A tight and uneasy horror film that delivers in suspense over scares.

Review title: In the country no one can hear you scream (rental)
Review_body: It's funny but this SK work reminds me of one of my greatest scary movie when I was a kid: it's a old (1975) french movie titled La Cage featuring Lino Ventura (as athletic as Caan) who is trapped in the basement by his crazy ex wife (is this pain a women trademark?). Anyway this kind of story terrorizes me because it's dear home becoming a cruel enemy and being still is a terrible nightmare! So that's why this work has always resonates with me. If the novel (among the last good ones SK wrote) had boring stuff (this goddess thing), the movie was attacked for the foot affair and the exterior scenes: I don't really mind because it features the excellent and future David Lynch old hero from Straight Story! I hoped that the audio commentary from the screenwriter would be interesting but his memory fails about this long past and he doesn't speaks much. Maybe Bates won the Oscar for it but I prefer her as Dolores Claiborne. I never liked much Caan (except in Rollerball) so maybe he is good here because for one time, he is less bragging Anyway I found his room and the cottage very cozy in a beautiful setting so the movie is enjoyable if you look to be stressed without bloody gore...

There are a lot of mediocre to bad King movie adaptions around, luckily Misery does not belong to them. What we get is a fine thriller with some bows into the direction of the art of horror, on top we get with Kathy Bates and James Caan some fine actors who give us some of their finest work. Always a nice game to watch. Last note: also recommended, Dolores Claiborne, another King adaption with a fine performing Kathy Bates.

Review title: Reiner and King Make a Hitchcock Movie
Review_body: As much as I love Reiner and King in their heydays, I don't know why it took me so long to see this. Oddly enough, it's more like a fantastic Hitchcock film than either one of them, though. For a story so small, it never feels limiting; the characters fill it out beautifully. Bates is a force; she is scary, sad, and hilarious as a toxic Twitter fan in real life. However, I did not expect to love the sheriff and his wife so much, but I think their presence is a big part of what makes the kidnapping authentically disturbing.
Awesome kathy bates in one of best king movie adaptions

James Caan, Kathy Bates, Richard Farnsworth, Frances Sternhagen and Lauren Bacall star in Rob Reiner's 1990 thriller based on Stephen King's novel. Caan (The Godfather) plays Paul Sheldon, a best-selling novelist who gets in a bad car accident during a winter storm. He's rescued and nursed back to health by woman, Annie Wilkes (Bates) who happens to be his number one fan. Paul discovers that Annie is unbalanced and that his life may be in danger when he's held captive in her house. The late, Farnsworth plays Sheriff, Buster who investigates Paul's disappearance, Sternhagen plays Buster's wife & deputy, Virginia and Bacall plays Paul's agent, Marcia Sindell. This is a great film, Caan and Bates are terrific in it, especially Bates and Mark Shaiman's score is also good. I recommend this.

Misery is a 1990 thriller starring James Caan(Elf) and Katy Bates(Titanic) and tells the tale of a successful writer named Paul(Caan)who is involved in a car crash and is taken in by a quirky woman who happens to be a nurse called Annie Wickes(Bates). But what happens after that is Paul to escape Annie who turns into a complete nutjob as she is an obsessed fan of Paul's who wants him to write her another story based on Misery at her cabin.The acting is good,the story keeps you in the edge of your seat and yes it can be somewhat gruesome to watch.

Making a novel isn't all that bad, even if the fan is more disturbed than the character of a book. In "Misery" Stephen King brings it all in this motion picture. Here you have a very brilliant author, Paul Sheldon(James Caan) who leaves his house for New York. He leaves in his Mustang in the snow, loses control of the car, and wrecks it. When is rescued by a nurse named Annie Wilkes(Kathy Bates) very helpful, but very deadly! She is a big fan of Sheldon and is curious about her favorite character "Misery". She gives Paul all the care in the world, until she finally becomes unhinged. She's a murderous nurse. After finding out what kind of a person she is, he's in deep trouble. After finding her penguin is facing the other way, she drugged, strapped, and re-breaks Paul's legs. That scene is brutal, and gut wrenching especially when the left leg wrapped around that block! After being prisoner of that fiend, he manages to get to New York. Safe at last, or is he? Note to self, watch out for psychotic fans! This movie was very intense, and everyone in the movie were outstanding, including Caan and Bates. She was so amazing! Rating 5 stars!

Rob Reiner did a fantastic job in the direction of this film. What didn't go right was the adaptation, as usual. The "toning down" of the scenes and events for this movie was an atrocious way to rewrite this wonderful, if somewhat short for King, novel.Kathy Bates is exceptional in her role as Annie Wilkes, a fan of (James Caan) Paul Sheldon's novels. Finding him stranded and unconscious in a snowdrift, she takes him home and attends to his needs until he regains consciousness. That's when the weirdness begins; in the movie's story, as well as the wide angle shots perpetrated upon the actors in their close ups. The deviations from the principal storyline really took away from this movie a great deal. That having been said, the feeling of discorporation you experience from the cinematography of the movie leaves you feeling disturbed and unsettled. Classic King. But again, the deviations just left me saying within the first 15 minutes ... WTF?! It was commonly predictable, horribly off-kilter, and widely uneven. The performances were perfect, but the adaptation left too much to be desired for this to be even moderately enjoyable.It rates a 4.0/10 from...the Fiend :.

Welcome to every author's nightmare. When famous writer Paul Sheldon (James Caan) flips his car during a blizzard, he is miraculously "rescued" by Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates)  his self-confessed number one fan. However, as he sits in her guest room with two broken legs, waiting for the snow-blocked roads to clear, he could never have imagined just how obsessed this woman actually is. Though Sheldon became famous for writing a series of novels featuring heroine Misery Chastain, he has since grown to hate this character, unceremoniously killing her off in his latest story, "Misery's Child," and setting to work on a "real" novel. When Wilkes finds this out, she is absolutely livid with rage, taking Sheldon as her effective captive and forcing him to write a sequel in which her favourite literary character is resurrected.Legendary horror author Stephen King has often excelled at writing stories about characters who are themselves authors, some of them no doubt inspired (hopefully only partially) by his own personal experiences. Some of these have been translated to the screen with masterful results (such as Stanley Kubrick's 'The Shining'), whilst others have not been quite as successful (David Koepp's 'Secret Window' was saved only by a solid performance from Johnny Depp). 'Misery' is most certainly one of the former, a nail-biting suspense thriller that will leave you feeling both excited and drained.James Caan is very good as Sheldon, a man faced with a terrifying situation in which he is helpless to do anything. Likewise, Richard Farnsworth is very entertaining as Buster, the local town sheriff, who suspects that there might be something unusual about the author's disappearance. But full honours go, of course, to an Oscar-winning Kathy Bates, who is exceptional as Wilkes, snapping like clockwork between mild-mannered gushing and murderous animosity. Her chilling  but certainly not subtle  performance is not one that you are likely to forget quickly.

This has got to be the best king adaptation from book to movie.The story, The Best-selling novelist Paul Sheldon is on his way home from his Colorado hideaway after completing his latest book, when he crashes his car in a freak blizzard. Paul is critically injured, but is rescued by former nurse Annie Wilkes, Paul's "number one fan", who takes Paul back to her remote house in the mountains (without bothering to tell anybody). Unfortunately for Paul, Annie is also a head case. When she discovers that Paul has killed off the heroine in her favourite novels, her reaction leaves Paul shattered (literally)...I was on edge of my seat watching this movie, one scenes made me look away from scene did make me look away, it some scenes I was shouting at at the screen.Kathy Bates was incredible in this movie, she was fantastic playing evil Annie Wilkes so well in this movie and James Caan was Fantantic too.A Great Thriller, I give this movie a 10 out 10

Exciting film about a writer (Caan) held captive by a "devoted fan," played deviously by Oscar winner Kathy Bates. Rob Reiner's direction is swift and the script is quick paced and exciting. The best of the King adaptations.

Don't be fooled by the impressive credentials: this ugly, abusive excuse for a motion picture is just a trashy big-budget adaptation of yet another Steven King potboiler. Even worse, it's a transparent, masochistic revenge fantasy aimed straight at the fans who made King a success in the first place. The protagonist is (naturally) a brilliant novelist, crippled in an auto accident and left to the not-so-tender mercies of his number one fan, who systematically tortures him so that he can continue writing best-selling garbage. The plot is not unlike an inversion of 'The Shining', but without the added element of the supernatural to give it any horrific guilty pleasures. Yes, the point is made that writers are always at the mercy of their readers, but cool, rational man of letters James Caan is, on the evidence of his cathartic fury of violence at the climax of the film, little better than psycho fan Kathy Bates (no relation to Norman). In fairness, it should be noted that the original, downbeat ending to King's novel was sanitized to make the story more accessible, but not enough to hide the author's contempt and self-pity.

Review title: Director Rob Reiner takes some help from popular writer Stephen King to depict how crazy can a fan be ! ! ! !
Review_body: Most writers are extremely happy and somewhat proud to learn about their numerous fans as it helps them to ascertain the extent to which their popularity has reached. However,there is hardly any writer who is ready to subject one's writing skills to be tested by fans. These are precisely some behavioral traits which American director Rob Reiner chose to depict in "Misery" which is a faithful adaptation of a best selling novel authored by Stephen King. We get to see how a best selling author cannot please everybody with his/her writings as the reactions of an ordinary reader are completely different from those of a deranged fan. A large part of 'misery' is set in a house where a famous author has been held prisoner by his most ardent fan with a not so pleasant past. It is an ideal setting for psychological games where each party has to outsmart the rival in order to ensure one's survival. American actor James Caan looks perfect in his role as a caged person who would invent novel ways to free himself from the clutches of a deranged fan. American actress Kathy Bates is devilish to such a large extent that one is led to believe that the art and craft of "writing process" can be dictated as per the whims and fancies of a deranged fan. Lastly, before "Misery" there were not many people who were aware of how master of detective fiction Arthur Conan Doyle was nagged by his fans when he chose to kill "Sherlock Holmes" for some days.

Review title: Elevated by standout performances from James Caan and Kathy Bates
Review_body: Kathy Bates is absolutely awesome in this one. It is likely one of the best, if not the best, Stephen King adaptations. Reiner proves that he can pull off a good horror flick and James Caan simply elicits pity as the man who is at the mercy of his fan.

James Caan plays writer Paul Sheldon. When he crashes his car in a ferocious snow-storm, it proves to be a very bad day for him. For Annie Wilkes, it proves to be an improbably good day, for not only does she find and rescue him from the wreckage, but the situation allows her to look after a hero of hers – she is an his 'number one fan' – as he convalesces in her spacious home.Every actor in this small cast has been blessed with a wonderfully expressive face. Director Rob Reiner seems very happy to film a lot of moments in close-up. This leads us to appreciate every raised eyebrow, every wistful look into space and to determine exactly the kind of mood Annie happens to be in on her latest visit to Sheldon's sickbed. The camera often almost zooms into her face as she walks into a scene – most effectively following the film's most harrowing scene which guarantees more than a wince, when she coos 'God, I love you.' She has his books set aside as soon as they are released, she has a documented – notorious even – history of violent, murderous behaviour, she walks around town with her pet pig and is clearly a tolerated local eccentric. And yet it takes local Sheriff Buster – yes, that's right (Richard Farnsworth), forever to conclude she may have something to do with his disappearance. Farnsworth has also been blessed with eloquent features, and we immediately warm to Buster's kindly ways. Which is just as well, because otherwise our patience would be sapped by his inability to recognise the blatantly obvious.So while the story takes a lot of investing into – the coincidence of Annie's hero falling into her proverbial lap, and the Sheriff's hopelessness – the cast and stark direction gives the production its legendary status.

This was a rather faithful adaptation of the Stephen King novel. The DVD jacket talks about how it required the correct director and cast, and they got both right. The leads were perfect with Kathy Bates (Oh, God, they got that right-she was great in that role and deserved her Oscar for her part) and James Caan as the writer who suddenly finds himself down on his luck and imprisoned by his number one fan. The interaction between the two leads was also great and led to an inevitable showdown. Of course, formula was used, but what movie doesn't use it? Basically, it was the type of movie that shows that you can make the most of a limited setting and a (mostly) limited cast. This was one of my favorite Stephen King novels-I think it was autobiographical in that he feels imprisoned to write horror. It was a horror story without the portrayal of monsters or demons.*** out of ****

Several factors make this horror film entertaining. First, the character of Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates) is so interesting. Living alone in an isolated farmhouse, nurse Annie comes across as resourceful, physical, observant, skilled, and competent. At the same time, she's naive, lonely, and delusional. Second, Kathy Bates animates the character with such verve and passion that we have no problem believing in Annie. She seems so real, so homely, such a kind, motherly woman, imperfect perhaps, with a slight temper. But hey, everyone is entitled to have a few imperfections.In addition, the script's dialogue exudes humor throughout. At a candlelit dinner on a card table, as a melancholy Liberace song plays in the background, Paul (James Caan) patronizingly asks Annie how she makes such great meatloaf. With great sincerity and pride, she responds: "My secret is I only use fresh tomatoes ... and to give it that little extra zip, I mix in some Spam with the ground beef". Marvelous.The script's theme is likewise ingenious. Paul, as a famous writer, commands respect and power. By contrast, Annie is a nobody, common and powerless. Yet, the story flip-flops the power structure, and places Annie in control. We sympathize with Paul. But we respect Annie. And ultimately, this is a story about Annie Wilkes, not Paul Sheldon.Competent cinematography, detailed set design, amplified sound effects, and good support performances all enhance the film's production.My only quibble is the casting of pugnacious James Caan as Paul; I would like to have seen what Dustin Hoffman or Robert Redford could have done with the role. Also, the film's climax is a tad over-the-top."Misery" is a slow-moving story about a lonely woman whose outward humanitarian behavior camouflage sinister motives, as she traps a famous writer in her rural sanctum. It's a fine film. And Kathy Bates certainly deserved her academy award.

Review title: One of my absolute favorites, a true classic!!
Review_body: Oh my gosh, one of the most well deserved Oscar wins of all time!!! Kathy Bates was a shining star in this movie! She really brought Annie Wilkes to life on the big screen! I have not read the book, but I don't need to in order to KNOW that this is a fantastic movie! I really don't know how anyone could hate this masterpiece! And also I love how the film makers didn't bog it down with constant profanity and sex! It was fairly clean for an R rated film. It's obvious why this is considered a Classic! I watch it every time it comes on a channel on TV, I never miss it! There are just "those" movies that never get old, you can watch them a gazillion times, and every time is as great as the last!

Wonderfully uncomfortable movie. A very interesting script keeps you engaged and rooting for the lead to get out of the nightmarish situation. Good characters, slow pace, but nice and engaging. Stand the test of time.

Review title: Will have you glued to it
Review_body: Rob Reiner has faithfully brought Stephen King's very frightening novel to the screen here with the movie "Misery". He manages to keep the audience gripping the edge of their seats as he creates a real claustrophobic type terror through the situation of 'Paul Sheldon' (James Caan), a writer who finds himself trapped in the home of his obsessive 'number one fan' (Kathy Bates) after she rescues him from a car accident in the remote Colorado mountains.This film comes highly recommended to all suspense and Stephen King fans, especially given the outstanding Academy Award winning performance from Kathy Bates. Just imagining what will happen next will keep you glued to this, if you can handle it.Tuesday, September 29, 1992 - VideoReiner's taught direction and Kathy Bates' marvellous, unnerving performance make "Misery" a chilling, suspenseful film that shouldn't be missed by Stephen King and Horror/suspense fans.James Caan and the editing crew are also worth an honourable mention. Scary stuff!Saturday, April 24, 1993 - Video

Review title: A must see...Kathy Bates is perfect and
Review_body: James Caan is surprisingly good. You must also read the book- even if you are not a fan of Stephen King- you will like this book, and find it horrifying.I just re-read the book again, and found many insightful passages. King's character "Annie Wilkes" is brought to life by Kathy Bates. A fictive personality, Wilkes is a schizoid psychotic, obsessed with writer Paul Sheldon (Caan).The setting is the isolated mountains of Colorado- Wilkes is a retired nurse, who initially helps Sheldon after a near-fatal car accident. It is not long before he realizes he is a captive audience, and Wilkes is his "Number one fan". Bates is believable because she is so unpredictable; one moment she is loving and protective; the next she is sharpening her ax.This film is suspenseful, and more terrifying because, unlike many of other King's adaptations, does not have the element of the supernatural. The fright factor is based on human nature, alone. That is one of the primary reasons most audiences will enjoy this film, even if they are not a fan of Stephen King.

Just like Shelley Duvall was born to play Olive Oyl, Kathy Bates was born to play Annie Wilkes.  Warren Beatty was offered the James Caan part, and I wish he had taken it; Caan is not believable as a romantic-novel writer, but it takes nothing away from Bates' performance.  If you ever read this, Rob Reiner, Thanks for the brilliant casting move.  Also enjoyable is the great Richard Farnsworth as the town sheriff.

Review title: Not as intense as the book, but more darkly comedic
Review_body: Ironically, the novel "Misery"--while as much about the nature of fan/celebrity relationships as the writing process itself, is not one of Stephen King's better-written works. Coming in at a relatively lean (for him) 338 pages, the novel IS a relentlessly intense tale of mounting terror and palpable desperation. Condensed by William Goldman into a more conventional, three-act narrative (the novel is essentially a prolonged standoff between the 2 main characters) and directed by Rob Reiner ("This Is Spinal Tap"), some of the novel's intensity has been lost, instead replaced by a gallows humor that hits more often than misses. Upon completion of his latest novel, best-selling author Paul Sheldon (James Caan) hops in his vintage Challenger just as a snowstorm comes up and sweeps him off a winding mountain road; he is rescued by Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates), an ex-nurse who resides on a well-isolated farm and is a raving psychotic. Reiner does a good job establishing the confined setting, amplified in Sheldon's own vain attempts at escape, while alternating with the husband-and-wife Sheriff-and-Deputy team (Richard Farnsworth and Frances Sternhagen in delicious roles) conducting their own search for the missing author. Caan and Bates play off one another wonderfully, and retain the "jousting" effect of King's characters; Bates, especially, becomes a well-rationed blend of the Terminator and a typical, small-town woman (complete with phrases like "cock-a-dookie")--a performance that could have veered into camp, but maintains a veneer of disturbing realism throughout.

Review title: A good adaptation for a King film, with some terrific performances
Review_body:
Well acted, and eerie in all the right ways, Misery may not be the most entertaining King adaptation, but it certainly is a good one. James Caan and Kathy Bates lead this terrifically acted adaptation of King's beloved novel, and do it with great ease. Bates is great at portraying the dangerous mood swings of her character, adn Caan great at trying to survive them. Their emotion, pain, and true effort they put into their characters is truly outstanding, and most certainly y favorite thing about the film. At times it can certainly be very thrilling, but other times the tone seems to fall flat, and become nothing short of dull. However, this is often saved by giving other plot points their well deserved treatment, and Reiner is able to keep the film alive with truly utilizing its strengths. In the end, Misery is not great, but a fairly good adaptation from one of my own favorite authors (although i'm hardly a #1 fan). It's acting is incredible, and though it may prove to be totally unstable from time to time, it finds its footing often enough to truly prove itself worthwhile.
My Rating: 8.5/10

Review title: "Mix a little spam with the ground beef"
Review_body: In our post-Hitchcock era, it's often forgotten how much design and formula there is to this kind of thriller, how a picture like this requires precision of timing and technique, space and structure. No matter how ingenious your concept and storyline are, if they're not presented properly they will no more thrilling than a dry account in a newspaper.Of course, one can't underestimate the importance of a good plot, and this one happens to be just such a work of ingenuity. Steven King's novel upon which Misery is based is one of the modern breed of real-life horror stories. These tend to be very effective if they can suggest a disturbing and perilous situation which any one of us can imagine and fear ourselves getting into. Granted, not every one of us is a celebrated novelist as Paul Sheldon is, but we could all conceivably be held at the mercy of some obsessive sociopath. And the business of the writer seemingly doomed to write the same trash over and over gives the story an added layer of interest, the characteristic hook that a good psychological thriller needs. Screenwriter William Goldman retains the core and most of the key aspects of King's novel, but condenses it well for the screen, also adding touches which keep it moving well for the motion picture format, such as the angle with the sheriff's investigation.And a good thriller, no matter how expertly written or constructed, needs a decent cast. Kathy Bates's portrayal of a murderous obsessive is incredibly believable in its superficial charm, mood swings and constant hint of the bizarre, but what really makes it brilliant is the way she works it for the needs of the movie. Her timing and delivery seem expertly calculated to make us wonder just when she will kick off again. In those moments of silence before she speaks, her expression is mysterious, unreadable, and we can't tell whether she is about to tell Paul she loves him or to savagely assault him. She even seems aware of the comical aspects of her own character, emphasizing Annie Wilkes's stranger utterances for comedic effect, without ever losing sight of the underlying realism of her performance. James Caan is very good too. His part here may consist chiefly of pained grimaces, but there is a certain art to that too which Caan has mastered.But these things would be worth little if they weren't put together properly. Misery seems like an unusual assignment for director Rob Reiner, who began his filmmaking career with the acclaimed mockumentary This Is Spinal Tap and followed it up with a series of warm-hearted comedy dramas like Stand By Me and When Harry Met Sally. And yet Reiner is an adaptable fellow because he does not seem to consider himself an artist – he simply applies himself to the needs of the picture, and as he himself has stated he actually set out to learn the techniques of making a thriller when he got signed for Misery. He learned good. Crucial here is Reiner's distortion of space, with lots of confusing close-ups and wide-angle lenses which flatten the foreground and pull the backgrounds forward. In the occasional wider shots of the bedroom where most of the movie takes place we see there is actually a lot of empty space around the bed, which gives us a bleak sense of isolation, and makes the surrounding walls seem all the more oppressive. Reiner even makes sure the scenes outside the house, such as those in the sheriff's office, are not too wide open, with few big landscape shots or visible skies. The audience may be privy to other goings-on, but we are not allowed to escape from the feeling of claustrophobia.The value of these techniques may seem a little tenuous – but they do genuinely work. Space, timing, and visual arrangements can have a strong psychological impact. It is crucial for a picture like this that we share in Paul Sheldon's sense of entrapment and helplessness. Reading a plot synopsis wouldn't be scary, but seeing the plot visually presented in the right way can be a terrifying experience. And this is also why there are so many thrillers out there that have a good idea but simply don't work in practice, or why sometimes an original movie can be brilliant but the remake is an unfortunate waste of celluloid. And the reason we don't often realise that we are being manipulated is that the very best directors do it so well we don't even notice.* * *Note: This is not an attempt to disparage King's novel by suggesting that written thrillers are not as good as cinematic ones. Novels have their own techniques for enthralling us, ones which Mr King is certainly well-versed in.

Stephen King does it again, over and over he proves that he is an outstanding writer and the film makers he works with keep putting on a great show.Considering how much of a wimp I am, it's amazing the amount of pleasure that I get from Kathy's sledgehammer antics and actually it's a huge surprise that I like this film as much as I do anyway, because I will never not be afraid of Kathy Bates. I don't care what role she is playing, I will always be prepared for her to be evil and sadistic. She is superb as Annie Wilkes, an unstable lunatic living in the middle of nowhere, who just happens upon her favourite author who's been in a car accident. What follows is a psychological thriller of the freakiest and creepiest happenings. James Caan does his best to keep it calm and polite, but she really did earn her Oscar. James does a good job too, but cannot possibly be as memorable as Mrs Bates.As a writer myself, I wonder if I will ever have such devoted fans. Only time will tell and I just hope that they aren't quite as unsavoury.

Review title: Perfect performances by Bates and Caan
Review_body: Based on the novel by him, 'Misery' is a real Stephen King film. It is a drama film, but also a thriller and sometimes even a horror. In one scene the horror is very clear, you will know what scene I mean.Writer Paul Sheldon (James Caan) gets in a car accident. He is helped by Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates) who claims she is his number one fan. In his latest novel Sheldon has killed the favorite character of Annie making her a little mad. She keeps Sheldon in her home; he has to bring the character back to life in his next novel.Bates, who won an Oscar, is terrific as Annie, one of her finest performances. James Caan who is in bed or a wheelchair most of the film is very convincing. The room he is living in is one of those spaces in the movies you will not forget very soon. Directed by Rob Reiner this is a great film, although it could be a bit slow for some from time to time.

I hadn't seen this film in years and wasn't quite sure how it would hold up, but it remains a strong example of a chamber piece horror film that excels at slow burn horror and suspense. James Caan plays romance novelist Paul Sheldon, who's in a horrific snowbound car wreck, but is "rescued" by his #1 fan Annie Wilkes, played by Kathy Bates in a brilliant and terrifying performance. Sheldon quickly realizes his savior is in reality holding him captive, but there is little he can do due to the remoteness of her house and his wheelchair bound state. What ensues is an game of cat-and-mouse between Caan and Bates that is suspenseful, frightening, and utterly thrilling. The film is tightly directed by Rob Reiner ("Stand by Me" "A Few Good Men" "The Princess Bride" "When Harry Met Sally" etc.) and is smartly script by William Goldman ("Magic" "Marathon Man" and the under-appreciated "Dreamcatcher," along with non-genre classics like "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" "All the President's Men" and "The Princess Bride") based on a Stephen King novel. Goldman's script gets major kudos for making this chamber piece horror film believable. Sheldon is an intelligent character and Goldman has him try all of the things an intelligent person would do in order to try to escape, which makes the situation all the more terrifying. Caan is perfectly cast in the role of Sheldon, a tough macho on-screen personality who finds himself uncharacteristically laid low, making this plights all the more alarming. But it's Bates who steal the show as Sheldon's obsessed and deranged fan, who's determined to keep him all to herself at any cost. In terms of the cast, Richard Farnsworth is memorable as a small-town sheriff investigating Sheldon's disappearance, as is Frances Sternhagen who plays his wife. It's also a treat to see Lauren Bacall in a small supporting role as Sheldon's publisher, but for the most part, the film is Caan and Bates and they are both at the top of their game. Overall, "Misery" is a class act of a horror movie, which is a rare occurrence, and is essential viewing for fans King, Caan, Bates, or of horror films or thrillers in general. SPOILER ALERT! The hobbling scene still shocks today and is just as cringe inducing as ever.
