Misery (1990): Kathy Bates, James Caan, Lauren Bacall, Richard Farnsworth, Frances Sternhagen, Graham Jarvis, Jerry Potter, Thomas Brunelle, June Christopher, Julie Payne, Archie Hahn III, Gregory Snegoff, Wendy Bowers, J.T. Walsh... Director Rob Reiner, Screenplay William Goldman.A Writer's Fan From Hell"Misery" was writer William Goldman's film adaptation of the popular Stephen King novel and directed by Rob Reiner. Released in December of 1990, this is now a nearly forgotten tale of terror. In truth, "Misery" was never as successful and memorable as other Stephen King classics- "Carrie", "The Shining", "Children of the Corn". The title "Misery" is a play on words- Misery is the fictional heroine in the film and also hints at the misery Sheldon experiences. James Caan portrays the acclaimed novelist Paul Sheldon, whose "Misery" series - about a beautiful and passionate heroine of the bodice-ripper/Harlequin romance kind- have stirred the imagination of millions of readers. Among them is Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates), a lonely widow and retired hospital nurse living in a secluded home in wintry Colorado. When Paul, en route to his Colorado home to work on his next novel, is caught in a blizzard, his car tips over and he is injured. Annie saves him and takes him home, where she nurses him back to health. But it doesn't take long for Paul to realize that this woman is dangerous and psychopathic. She has a criminal past- she killed several babies in hospitals where she worked. She keeps a grotesque pig as a pet. Far more than just a fan of his novels, she is obsessed with Paul Sheldon himself, keeping his photographs and articles about him. When she reads his latest manuscript, she is upset that he kills off his Misery character and demands he write a new novel in which she returns to life. Paul spends a long time trapped in her home, forced to write the novel and forced to battle the crazed Annie herself. At the time of the film's release, this movie received an R rating for the language and the violence. The violence derives from the character of Annie, who is mentally unstable and causes Paul bodily harm. This film is, for me, very engaging as a work of somewhat realistically drawn horror. The fact this film does not feature the supernatural elements that Stephen King is best known for (ghosts, demons, possessions)is a refreshing change. The horror in this film is found in the troubled nature of Annie Wilkes. She is a religious lunatic (she thinks God send Paul to her), socially maladjusted (doesn't have friends, family, job, her husband is dead) and her idea of love is warped. Too many viewers at the time of the release, her breaking Paul's legs and other tortures were too graphic to be seen on the screen. How times have changed! William Goldman, best known for great novels and film adaptations, seems to be in a kind of subtle battle with King's original vision. King clearly wants us to fear this woman and loathe her. But Goldman hints at a woman we should feel sorry for- she is a vulnerable, pathetic woman who is lonely and unhappy, desperate for social contact and love. Because she is so isolated and friendless, she becomes crazy. This madness, believe it or not, seems to derive from her fantasy life, from the life of her inner mind. In the character of Sheldon's Misery, she finds comfort, hope and confidence, as if she is living vicariously through a fictional character. She does not care that this role model Misery is a made-up creation. It would interest some people to know that such crazed fans exist. Some readers become so familiar with an author and their work that they become obsessed. This is a great film and if you enjoy Stephen King, you are sure to love this. Kathy Bates and James Caan have genuine chemistry on screen. Kathy Bates delivers a sensational performance, revealing depth and versatility as an actress. She far outshines James Caan and it is this film that appears to have made her a star that Hollywood took a bigger interest in.

And yet again, I was surprised in a very positive way by a Stephen King adaptation. I mean, if somehow you've written the stories to the Shawshank Redemption, The Green Mile, The Shining AND Stand By Me, you should consider him a genius, but somehow I don't. Maybe the many lousy TV-series like The Langoliers or It prevent that. But right here we have another example of a great story, and I must say, filmed superbly: Misery... How to make a movie this interesting with just 2 characters is amazing. Obviously, you need 2 good actors. No problem here: Caan and Bates are intense and brilliant. Comic relief comes from the ol' Sherrif's couple, now all you need is a good ending... which IS good (though not great, especially the leap in time at the end) with Caan killing off Bates with his typewriter... In short: great movie, even a bit of a classic if you'd ask me: 9/10.

Review title: A decent thriller, nothing special though
Review_body: Misery is not the best thriller, but its far from the wort. The cast does well with a good script and limited directing from Reiner. Rob Reiner's thriller based on Stephen King novel is another average thriller, however this one unlike Zemeckis' 2000 film what lies beneath has a better cast and screenplay. Although the film does have some unexpected moments and a few good scenes, as a whole its a bore and the characters are a bit stereotyped. The acting saved this film, Bates is great in her Oscar winning role and Caan and Farnsworth were great too. THis film is written well by William Goldman and directed averagely by Reiner who impressed me much more with The American President. This is a good movie but not great 8/10

Adaptations of Stephen King books are notorious for being subpar to the books, and Misery is one of them. The book is excellent, King's best next to The Shining, and has never ending terror. The movie version isn't as good.James Caan is a popular romance novelist, he writes the Misery books, about Misery Chastain, a rich 19th young woman. Millions of fans love her, including Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates, in an Oscar-winning role), who finds Paul Sheldon and brings him to her house after a car crash. At first, she's treating him nicely, but after she reads his first draft of a new book that she doesn't like, and she finds out that in his latest Misery book that Misery dies, Annie gets angry. When Annie gets angry, back away.She makes Paul burn the book she doesn't like, and then Annie keeps Paul captive to write a book: Misery's Return. Since Paul's bedridden with no use for his legs, he can't leave, and if he tries to, Annie will do things to him. One is with a mallet.If you haven't read the book, then most of this review will be worthless, since whenever I see a movie based on a book I have read, my review will be a comparison. Now that that's out of the way, let me go on. The book had nonstop thrills, while in this movie adaptation the thrills varied. Obviously, I knew what was going to happen, but what really made this a good film was the acting.Kathy Bates well deserved her best actress Oscar for this demanding role. Not many people COULD play Annie Wilkes, but Bates is the only person who I could imagine for this role. I was looking forward to seeing her do another great acting job, since I had just seen her in About Schmidt. Caan was also very good, but it's obvious why he didn't win an Oscar. It's really a two-person show, except Richard Farnsworth and Lauren Bacall come in as a police chief and Caan's agent, respectively.To be forewarned is to be forearmed, and there is one brutal scene with a sledgehammer, but that's all I'll say. Much of the violence from the book is taken out, which makes it easier to read. To sum it up, Misery's thrills come and go, but there's some great acting here.My rating: 7/10Rated R for a scene of violence.

I really enjoyed watching this. This movie came out on the year I was born, so it makes it extra special for me to see. I never actually thought it would be this thrilling though. I've seen many thrillers, but not too many were as thrilling and scary as Misery.Kathy Bates was outstanding in this movie. She was perfect to play "Annie Wilkes" and I don't think any other lady could've played it any better. Let's not forget James Caan who played "Paul Sheldon" - he was very good. They were like two sides of the same coin, and that's what made Misery such a great movie.The movie keeps you guessing: it's unpredictable. It had me on the edge of my seat. The character Kathy Bates played (Annie Wilkes) was horrifying - a true psychopath. Annie Wilkes was very scary especially when she's angry. We should be glad that something like this doesn't happen to us in the way she treats Paul Sheldon.I like the title of the movie (Misery) because it's not just based of the book, but it was also a "Misery" time for Paul Sheldon.This is one of my favourite Stephen King's adaptation, and it's probably one of his best.Personally, I'm not into the horror genre, but if there was a horror movie I wanted to see when I was a lot younger, Misery would be my choice. Honestly, if I saw Annie Wilkes behaving the way she does in this movie, I'd have nightmares frequently. Misery is a movie where you should turn-up your volume - just trust me on that.

Paul Sheldon (James Caan) is a very successful author of romance and thriller books, one snowy night he crashes his car and a lonely woman named Annie (Kathy Bates) rescues him then provides shelter for him. She happens to be Sheldon's biggest fan and would do anything to be with him as her wish has come true, but she's a bit on the psychotic side as she wants him to write a new novel based on her wish-fulfillment ideas even if she won't allow Sheldon to leave.A twisted and stylish modern horror thriller that is very faithful to Stephen King's novel of the same name and is adapted by William Goldman and directed wonderfully by Rob Reiner. The film also co-stars Lauren Bacall, this is one of the best cinematic horror and thriller films ever! In fact, Kathy Bates won best actress for the part of Annie. This is a disturbing film with memorable moments like the horrifying foot torture scene you won't forget and of course atmosphere galore, the acting is phenomenal as well! this movie is a real winner.Also recommended: "Black Christmas (1974)", "Tourist Trap", "Funny Games", "Psycho (1960)", "The Shining", "Dolores Claiborne", "Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer", "Hostel 1 & 2", "Silence of the Lambs", "Audition", "Dressed To Kill", "Manhunter", "Hannibal", "Red Dragon", "Hannibal Rising", "Se7en", "Pin..", "May", "The Others", "Deep Red (1975)", "Tenebre", "Macabre (1980)", "When a Stranger Calls (1978)", "Psycho II", "Psycho III", "Psycho IV: The Beginning", "Vertigo", "North by Northwest", "Rope", "Basic Instinct", "Nightmare (a.k.a. Nightmare in a Damaged Brain)", "Silent Night Deadly Night", "Dead Ringers", "Wolf Creek", "Original Sin", "The Hitcher (1986)", "Secret Window" "Perfect Blue" and "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre (1974)".

Review title: Rob Reiner knows how to direct
Review_body: Misery tells the story of Paul Sheldon, plays by James Caan, and when he wipes out in a car accident, Annie Wilkes, played by Kathy Bates, finds him and takes him back to her house, as the months progress, Annie grows more and more psychopathic as Paul Sheldon writes Misery out of his new book.Rob Reiner achieved Hitchcockian level direction with this movie, and Annie Wilkes and James Caan are excellent, her performance is easily on my top 10 favorite performances list, and the ending, the look on her face as Paul is about to burn this paper, is perfect, Misery is one of the best thrillers of the 90's, and it absolutely deserves an A+

Review title: One of the finest Stephen King adaptations i've ever seen
Review_body: Rob Reiner once said after watching Stanley Kubrick's "The Shining" (1980) he was inspired to make a movie based on Stephen King's work, and four years after he directed "Stand by Me" (1986) he prepared himself for directing this movie by watching every single film by the legendary "Master of Suspense" himself Alfred Hitchcock. As the film opens we see a very famous novelist named Paul Sheldon (James Caan) drive his car in a snowstorm to his publishers' office to take a look at a novel in his "Misery" series that he had just finished but he never gets there because he's in a snowstorm and rolls down a hill covered in snow while still in his car, he then is bleeding with a bunch of cuts and broken bones on him. Sheldon is then dragged out of his car and rescued by his self-proclaimed #1 fan who is a licensed nurse named Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates) who takes care of him and nurses him back to health. During the next few days Sheldon's agent Marcia Sindell (Lauren Bacall) is very suspicious as to where Paul Sheldon is and then tells the local sheriff (Richard Farnsworth) to help find Sheldon and get the book published. As the film progresses we see that Wilkes is getting crazier and more psychotic in every single scene she is in and holds Sheldon hostage while mistreating him because she didn't like the latest and unpublished addition to his series of "Misery" novels as well as going so far as to burn all of the pages and make him write another book just so she can like the revised edition that he is being forced to do, and Sheldon is doing anything he can possibly think of to stay alive. I won't spoil anything else beyond this point in the review because I feel that the scenes after the climax are way too important to spoil. Reiner and his screenwriter William Goldman are very effective with the suspenseful dialogue, and Reiner's frequent composer Marc Shaiman's score only heightens the suspense all they way to a Hitchcockian level. The performances from both Caan (who gives his best performance since "The Godfather" (1972)) and Bates (who won an Oscar for her performance, which was well-deserved, and the best performance of her career) are top notch, and Bates' portrayal of Wilkes is one of the best portrayals of a psychopath that I've ever seen, which is on par with Anthony Perkins in "Psycho" (1960), Anthony Hopkins in "The Silence of the Lambs" (1991), Piper Laurie in "Carrie" (1976), Robin Williams in "Insomnia" (2002), Heath Ledger in "The Dark Knight" (2008), Jack Nicholson in "The Shining" (1980), and Christoph Waltz in "Inglourious Basterds" (2009). It is movies like this that prove that Rob Reiner is a directorial chameleon because he can make a good movie out of anything that is given to him, for example a courtroom drama like "A Few Good Men" (1992), and a children's movie like "The Princess Bride" (1987). This isn't the best movie that I've seen based on Stephen King's work but it's pretty darn close to it.

Kathy Bates delivers an unsettling and terrifying performance as James Caan's "number one fan." She deserves the praise she gets for this role as it is truly an all-timer. The writing and direction are excellent, managing to maintain solid suspense and surprises throughout. I'd be remiss not to point out the superb cinematography. The impressive close-ups on Bates when she has her memorable outbursts are key in conveying her volatility and frightening presence. My only complaint is the film feels slightly too long, but that's a minor issue. Misery is a great thriller and one of the best adaptations of Stephen King's books.

Misery have clearly some tense and scary moments. At the beginning we cant see the danger of the situation and the evilness of the female character but the situation become a lot scarier after we know her a little bit better. The movie have some tense moment and can be very good. I think it was very well adapted from the book of Stephen King. I enjoyed it very much.

I really enjoyed misery. And why shouldn't I? The cast did great, the plot was excellent the pace made sure you were standing still on your seat, in other words it has all it takes for a good film to be such.Caan and Bates have done an excellent job and as far as the storyline goes I'll just say it is another Stephen King Novel. In this instance I cannot remember any King novel made movie that I did not like.With an excellent script, scenery, and a highly charged atmosphere Misery surely makes an interesting watch.9/10

"Misery" is a phenomenal and stunning film. Rob Reiner has done an amazing job with this adaptation of Stephen King's novel. I loved James Caan's performance, this is probably one of his best performances along with "The Godfather". Kathy Bates is terrifying and her performance just gives me chills, her performance does give a lot to the film. What I most loved about the film was one specific scene: when the Sheriff of the town comes to investigate the disappearance of Paul Sheldon and appears at Annie Willkes house. Then gets killed. The similarity between this scene and the scene from Psycho where the private investigator gets killed at the Bates motel are amazing.

The way Paul is going to escape from the clutches of Annie is what makes this movie interesting, and in this sense Misery is particularly efficient because this plot offers tense scenes and manages to captivate the viewer's attention from start to finish. Kathy Bates is, by the way, excellent in her torturer psychopath role, as opposed to James Caan who seems a bit uncomfortable.In fact, the real problem is the movie lacks heaviness and darkness to be totally convincing. Annie could have been much more demoniac, and Paul's character lacks credibility, particularly in his behaviour. The atmosphere seems therefore a bit sugarcoated and that is the big downside to this movie, that deserves no more than the average mark.

Misery is probably Stephen King's most frightening story because of the way it grounds in reality how one person can be living his life, and then suddenly be thrust into the most terrifying ordeal he has ever experienced. Its a refreshing change from King's supernatural stories.Don't be mislead by the title. Misey is far from a miserable experience. Its a gripping, tightly wound thriller from startling beginning to nail-biting conclusion.The film begins with novelist Paul Sheldon (James Caan) finishing a new novel. But one that is different from the "Misery books" he has become famous for. He feels that writing about Misery Chastaine for so long has stifled his creativity. So after he finishes his brand new novel, he checks out of the Silver Creek lodge, and goes for a drive. Unfortunately, a blizzard sends his car off the road.When he wakes up, he finds himself in the home of nurse Annie Wilkes (the superb Kathy Bates). As a result of the accident, Paul is now temporarily crippled. This is not a good thing, in more ways than one. Gradually, Paul (and the audience) realises that Annie is dangerously unstable. She claims to be his "number one fan". She's completely obsessed with him and his Misery novels. She is none to happy to discover in his latest novel, Misery dies. And she wants Paul to write a new novel, heralding Misery's return.So begins the battle of wits between Paul and Annie, as he desperately tries to find a way to escape. There is a real claustrophobic feel to Misery, thanks in no small part to Coen cinematographer Barry Sonnenfeld's tight, unnerving camera angles. They do a great job of capturing Paul's horror at being at Annie's mercy. As most of the film takes place within the confines of his room, Paul must find a way to out-think Annie. But she always seems to be one step ahead.James Caan gives a good enough performance as Paul Sheldon, keeping a subtle, slightly cynical attitude while at the same time terrified of his situation. But the real star of the film is Kathy Bates. She is just brilliant, and steals every scene she is in. The audience is transfixed by how one minute she is a caring, slightly eccentric person, and than suddenly changes to a psychotic, homicidal lunatic. Sometimes she is downright evil.The "hobbling" scene is especially memorable. A demonstration of Annie's power over Paul. Thwarting his attempts to escape. Breaking his spirit. The relationship between the two characters is skilfully handled, as Annie tries to keep Paul to herself forever in the name of love!What terrifies you the most is the way Annie's delusions are the only thing keeping her from killing Paul outright. She would willingly sacrifice both their lives to ensure Misery lives. Although Annie Wilkes is a terrifying creation, she is a sometimes sympathetic character. One wonders what could have possibly happened to Annie to make her so demented. Kathy Bates deserved the Oscar for this film. One of the rare occasions the committee got it right.The novel told the story completely within the confines of Annie's home, but the film includes other characters too. Richard Farnsworth's Sheriff Buster is a likable character. His relationship with his sarcastic wife is fun to watch. Sometimes, it feels like he is the only person looking for Paul. Lauren Bacall puts in a cameo as Paul's agent. Its a pity she couldn't have got more screen time. But this was probably an attempt to keep up the psychological tension between Paul and Annie.The ending is extremely suspenseful, as things inevitably come to a head. The audience (unless you've read the novel) is kept guessing about the outcome. Almost like a Hitchcock film. Kudos to Rob Reiner for making a thoughtful, suspenseful, psychological thriller. Kathy Bates rules. Misery recaptures everything that made the novel so great. It beats the film version of The Shining hands down. Brilliant!
LOVED Kathy Bates in this movie!!! What a FULL ON NUTTER!!! She did to writers what Glenn Close did to all cheating men in Fatal Attraction. LOL ;D.

In one of Stephen King's more practical stories, Misery, a reputable versatile Hollywood director, Rob Reiner took the reins on what his known to be one of the higher regarded King adaptations. Misery has a very thin cast and relies on the screen presence and dialogue of Kathy Bates and James Caan to execute a quality movie. Bates especially, to pull off the compelling, outright switch of extreme personalities changes is a difficult feat that was accomplished superbly. Another part of the film's approach is to focus on precise details of scenes, character actions, mannerisms, props, setting and authenticity. At times some scenes and dialogue almost seem excessive in length, slowing down the film. Seriously, the plot of his Misery books gets in the intensity of the film. However, the film has some great payoffs with a few scenes, one being extraordinarily memorable. Misery is an excellent film that requires patience, empathy and respect to its context in time.

Review title: dun din ding dun din ding etc
Review_body: yes, moonlight sonata used to perfection, just like in Resident Evil. the music is just one of the key factors which makes Misery a top class horror movie. The first of the Stephen King adaptations on my top 150 list, Misery may be the most frightening. Combining the paranoia which comes from writing block, with the fear of obsessive fans, Reiner has made one of the most suspenseful movies of the Nineties. Bates is superb, Cann shows his versatility (that of his feet in particular), although it does end up being another Terminator clone in the last half hour as Annie Wilkes just wont die. 8 out of ten
From the mind of Stephen King, it's not so much a Horror in the jumpy sense, but one of situational frustration, building on through what appears to be a strangers kindness.

Review title: Maybe one of the best thrillers ever made?
Review_body: MISERY - 1990Directed by Rob ReinerStarring James Caan, Kathy Bates and Richard FarnsworthPlot Overview: After his car crashes on an icy day, renowned author, Paul Sheldon(James Caan) is picked up by sweet seeming Nurse, Annie Wilkes(Kathy Bates), whom all happens to be his number 1 fan. All is going well until Wilkes reads the end of the latest instalment of her favourite series and discovers her favourite character has met her end. In a psychotic twist, Wilkes turns against Sheldon and forces him to rewrite the story with a different ending.THIS is a good thriller. I was on the edge of my seat for the entire run time of this movie. I didn't even know I could bite that far down on my nails! It is a masterfully written, sensationally acted, expertly shot and edited masterpiece. It is truly exceptional. I cannot recommend this movie any more. Please see this wonderful movie.The plot of this movie is horrifying. King is known for his horror but what is more scary than being at the mercy of some psychotic nurse who is your only chance of survival and can end your life at any moment. You can't escape; you can't fight back; it's you and her and there is nothing you can do about it. THAT is a scary. That is a trademark of great horror. Sometimes a great horror/thriller doesn't need ghosts or an overabundance of gore. It just needs a terrifying idea and it is instantly effective.To say one minor issue I have in regards to the story, it is a little plot hole to do with the end. It makes, no logical sense and I would have liked some more explanation; just a throwaway line or two, explaining what happened. I understand the jist of it but I can't say what I would like explaining without spoiling the film and I will not do that because you need to see this film.Kathy Bates is equally hilarious and terrifying in this Oscar worthy portrayal of Annie Wilkes. She commands this movie and enjoys every, single second it it. It is truly a remarkable performance and 100% deserved the Oscar.A performance that goes under-looked in this film due to Bates' focus that I think is unjust is James Caan's excellent performance as Paul Sheldon. Obviously, Bates is the star of this film and gives the best performance but Caan gives an incredible performance as well. He has to act while acting and that will be a genuinely hard thing to make convincing.Richard Farnsworth is excellent as Buster(the sheriff). The back and fourth humour between him and his wife is perfect and really helps give you time to breathe amidst the intensity going on around you.Both the cinematography and editing in this movie are superb. They help give the film a tight focus and an eerie claustrophobic feel. It makes the film all the more terrifying. Both the costume and set design are excellent, also and give a sense of authenticity to the film.Overall, I absolutely adore this movie. It is a masterfully crafted thriller and I cannot recommend it any more. You have to see this movie without spoilers because it truly is terrifying. This movie is a masterpiece and thus I shall rate it 10 Sledgehammers out of 10.

Misery tells the story of an author who his famous off his series of Misery novels. On his way home from a secluded lodge, he is in a violent car wreck that breaks both his legs. He is rescued by a local woman who claims to be his #1 fan. She takes him in, feeds him, takes care of him, and gushes over his Misery novels. However, when she reads his latest novel in which he kills the character off for good, she snaps and begins to torment him, forcing him to write a new Misery novel. This movie is a perfect psychological thriller, almost like a Hitchcock movie.Stephen King writes some great novels, but Misery is one of his greatest. In the late 80s, Stephen King novels were hot properties for films, and with the great success of Misery, it was only a matter of time before they made a movie out of it. The first good sign was that Rob Reiner took the helm. He had previously done a fantastic job bringing Stephen King's The Body to the big screen as Stand By Me. Next, the role of the author was taken by James Caan, who is one of the most talented actors out there. I really enjoyed William Goldman's screenplay, because it stayed true to the book while also adding some things to make it more interesting. The blend of terror and comedy in some scenes is perfect and it makes the movie really enjoyable. I especially love the scene where the woman brutally injures the author, and the next day she gleefully waves at him, and he just nonchalantly waves back...With his finger.The acting in this movie is great. There's only about 5 roles that really mean anything, and the actors are all great. This is one of James Caan's best performances, and it's only matched by Kathy Bates' performance as the crazed fan.Overall, Misery is a classic movie, and it is the best Stephen King movie besides The Shawshank Redemption. Great, great movie.9/10

I've got personal beef with about 95% of King adapted films as for some reason I can't get on with his lack of originality and at times his works feel overly complicated and pretentious but nevertheless I went into this with some knowledge of its appreciation. I wouldn't go as far as saying I enjoyed it as it felt a bit bland as you'd expect from a film which essentially depicts cabin fever in some form it's really at times very outdrawn and bland, however for every 10 minutes of boredom there is a good handful of entertaining moments and really ingenious use of film form which require 100% attention and lack satisfying pay offs. But as you might expect, you can't really save a film from the odd moment and such it's largely uninteresting and frankly does have many close running parallels to Psycho now I think about. A lesser film than its 'inspiration' the performances and the odd moment are really all you can take away from this, but in fairness it's in my bracket of 'liked' (and I use that word very lightly) King adaptations

To be honest, I got to know about this movie on twitter. I decided to watch it and after watching it, I thought why people don't talk about this movie anymore. It looks like people have forgotten about this movie.Movie was very nicely made. The main leads did a brilliant job, especially Kathy Bates. She did her role so perfectly, it felt as if this role was meant for her only. You will start hating her character, which is meant to be hated and will start getting afraid of her whenever her scene comes. The story was taken from Stephen King's novel and I think they did decent job in adapting it. The direction was good but felt weak in some parts. The pacing and environment setting was spot on.Overall, this movie should be given a try. I think it's too much underrated and it deserves to reach wider audience.

Misery is one of a few choice Stephen King novels that has been successfully turned into a film. With the brilliant and twisted way Stephen King is able to bring forth a story and the exceptional directing of Rob Reiner, Misery is able to succeed. James Caen and Kathy Bates star in the lead roles and are both perfect for their roles.Paul Sheldon is one of the most successful authors in the country and is driving his car on a windy and snowy mountain road. Next thing you know, Paul has crashed his car and is being rescued by a large woman. Paul wakes up too find himself in a large house in a rural valley. A sweet woman by the name of Annie is tending to him.Annie explains how she found him and how she treated his injuries. She tells him he can't leave due to seriousness of his injuries. Annie also explains that she is Paul's number one fan and absolutely loves his novels about Misery Chastain. Annie is sweet yet she has a darker side to her. She is bossy, she's mean, and she always wants her own way. Annie eventually asks Paul to write a story just for her about Misery Chastain. Paul is fine with that considering he is injured and can't really leave until his legs get better. Over the course of months, Paul writes for Annie. But soon Paul sees how he may never leave. When Paul's legs finally begin to get strength, Annie breaks his ankles so he won't leave. She begins to show her true side. Now Paul must use his deepest intellectual ability to find a way out of the house and out of his own misery in the house. James Caen holds the lead of Paul and is quite appealing as an author. He has that tone in his voice of being professional and likeness to him. You are easily able to see why Annie and so many others like him so much. The way he is able to think, especially with his plans to escape, are sheer genius and show how smart he really is. Kathy Bates gave the performance of her life. At the start she seems to be like a favorite aunt type character, she would be the relative you could always have a good time and laugh with. She is also one crazy lady in the film. She gets a trance in her eyes and it is some of the scariest moments I've experienced. The scene where James Caen wakes up and she is starring at him holding the sledge hammer haunted me for weeks. Both actors literally carry the movie. Other than a small performance by Richard Farnsworth, the two actors are the only two on the screen for 95% of the movie. Caen is his likable self, with a sly voice and a crafty mind. Bates is haunting in her role. She is so... so crazy, that is the only word I can describe her as. Rob Reiner has made a masterpiece of horror but not with bloody murders and monsters. No the greatest horror he makes is the horrors deep in the human mind and the closed environment of Annie's house. This movie will scare even the most veteran horror fans and send most waking with nightmares.4 1/2 out of 5 Stars
The movie is very good, suspenseful action and has excellent performances by James Caan and Kathy Bates.

Misery was a nice little surprise for me, since I wasn't expecting to like it very much. I've always abhorred Rob Reiner as a filmmaker, feeling that he's too flat and vanilla to bring any kind of weight to his material, but the premise and execution here are so simple that it would have been hard for him to mess it up. Thankfully he didn't and what I got was an entertaining thriller with a superb cast all around.Of course Kathy Bates is on fire with one of the most terrifying performances I've seen. I was worried at first that she was going to go over the top and become this absurd and grating display of theatrics, but I was surprised by how well she was able to balance the menacing insanity of Annie Wilkes with her eerie Marge Gunderson side. James Caan doesn't have to do much with such a strong antagonist, but he makes it easy for you to root for him and he is a constantly engaging presence. Richard Farnsworth was a surprise for me, giving such an honest and genuinely likable portrayal as the Sheriff.It's a thriller in a Hitchcock-vein, building suspense out of little moments and never relying on shock gags to frighten the audience. The intensity is built out of real feelings, and it truly does build and build over the course of the film. It becomes more frightening in locking this character in such a confined area, making the fear come more out of his inability to act than what is going on around him. You can create something as scary as you want but the most simple of monster becomes more terrifying when you aren't able to run or fight. A simple story told simply and it shouldn't have been done any other way.

Review title: Kathy Bates Still Leaves An Indelible Impression.
Review_body: It's fun to say that its almost been 5 years since I last saw "Misery", and I want to begin my review with a sentence I wrote all those years ago: "What a great Stephen King flick". Yes, Rob Reiner has delivered one of the more finer Stephen King adaptations. Though I have never read the novel, King himself stated that "Misery" is one of his favourite movies based on his works. James Caan & Kathy Bates have a really hard job to do keeping us entertained throughout the film. But the chemistry between the author and psychotic fan is so incredibly intense and unflinching in its depiction, it manages to elevate beyond expectations and still remain profound in the thriller genre today.Famed novelist Paul Sheldon (James Caan), is the author of a series of regency romance novels featuring a character named Misery Chastain. Whilst driving home he is caught in a blizzard and his car unfortunately goes off the road, leaving him unconscious. Paul is rescued from the wreckage by a nurse named Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates), who brings him to her remote home as Paul is broken and bed-ridden. She reveals to be Misery's "Number 1 fan", and inevitably Annie's fanaticism seems to go way beyond the norm, possibly leading to big trouble for the helpless Paul.It's so well acted and directed, you can get sucked in just like that. Even back then I loved how subtle and cool everything seemed in the beginning, then it just takes a turn for the worse until ultimately it turns into a battle of survival where the odds are completely stacked against you. Kathy Bates takes fanaticism to a whole new level, into the stuff of nightmares. She more than deserved the Oscar for such a career defining performance. James Caan does admirable work, I've always appreciated and enjoyed his performance and presence on screen. Final Verdict: Stephen King is my favourite author, and Rob Reiner adds another gem to his filmography. The performances alone are more than enough reason why I highly recommend seeing it. 8/10.

A really slow build, but a brilliant thriller, and one of the best adaptations of King's work. A film which offers very little in terms of settings and an abundance of characters, but this only develops the protagonist and antagonist further, building a palpable relationship.Bates is deserving of her Oscar in the role of Annie, switching personalities over scenes and creating a truly disconcerting character. Caan, likewise, is superb and displays the feelings of hope and despair well. The violence is limited for the majority of the film, making the intermittent bursts all the more uncomfortable. A brilliant slow burn film.

Review title: A Disturbing And Great Adaptation On King's Novel(SPOILERS)
Review_body: SPOILERSWhat can I say? I love this film. I always liked movies based on Stephen King's novel and this is in my top ten. I actually liked James Caan better in this than the Godfather, and he was great in the Godfather. Kathy Bate's performance was amazing. She totally deserved that Academy Award. I mean, her performance was spectacular.Here is the plot. Quite simple, really. The famous writer of the popular Misery books, now you know why the movie is called Misery, crashes his car and he is injured. He is rescued by a woman he helps him recover. No, she does not call the police. Anyway, that woman, ironically, is the writer's biggest fan. The writer is named Paul and the woman is named Annie, by the way. Anyway, after his new book comes out Annie finds out that Misery died in the book. Paul realizes that Annie is insane. She forces Paul to write a new book. When Annie is out Paul explores the house. Annie finds that out and tortures him. He burns the new Misery book and they get into a fight. He kills Annie and is treated at a hospital. Months later a waitress says she is his number one fan.Overall, this is a very tense, thrilling film. I liked Paul's remark after the waitress says that she is his number one fan. "That's very kind of you." Also, there is the hobbling scene. I am sure that every horror fan knows what that scene is. It is one of the most disturbing scenes in a horror film ever. Annie puts a block between Paul's leg and smacks his legs with a huge sledgehammer. His feet swing like a door opening. That was not even in the book. His feet are chopped off in the book. Anyway, this is a fantastic horror film.8/10Recommended Films: The Shining.

Chilling and dark -- a freak show that twists the knife every minute it can. Rob Reiner's Misery is a great film version to Stephen King's horrific novel.  The film is filled with subtle terror and wonderful acting by the two leads.  Kathy Bates is sensational as the demented Annie, and James Caan gives one of his best performances as the tortured Paul.  This film is great.There are a few flaws.  How does he bathe?  Where does he get his clothes? Those can be forgotten however; cause the film is so entertaining.

Review title: He used to write for a living; now he writes to stay alive
Review_body: *SPOILERS* Paul Sheldon (James Caan) is the writer of a long long series of romance books that have a heroine called Misery Chastain.After having finished writing the last book of the series, and aspiring to get to write something better, to upgrade himself, he decides to leave the hotel he was in and drive back home.Bad decision... he ends up having an accident, and is found and cured by former Nurse Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates), who admits being 'his Number One Fan'.Now, I know what you're thinking: 'why is this guy telling us he made a bad decision? Yeah, he had an accident and whatnot, but he's in good hands now after all, right?' DEAD WRONG.See, Annie is a complete and utter nutcase, and when she finds out that Paul has killed her beloved Misery in the last chapter of the book she goes insane and murderous, ordering Paul to burn his book and write a new adventure of Misery, trapping him in every way she can; and as he finds out just *how* dangerous Annie can actually be - she breaks both of his legs with a hammer as a punishment - he tries to find a way to get out, because he doesn't know what will Annie do with him after he finishes the new 'Misery' novel...Rob Reiner was mainly known for comedies at the time he made this movie, and took a huge risk in doing it. But it paid off; boy, did it pay off! It's one of the best Stephen King adaptations The casting for Paul Sheldon was actually very clever; James Caan is one of the most active guys in Hollywood, and being forced to stay in a bed for a long time, he was able to use his annoyance with his predicament to make people understand his character's growing uneasiness with the horrific situation he was in.Kathy Bates was a find; she manages to bring both sides of Annie (her normal, emotional side and her 'psycho from hell' side) to life, making them not only real, but believably in the same person, and won a very well-deserved Academy Award for it.In short, this is a winner.... Hey, you, what are you doing still there? C'mon, rent it (or better, buy it) and watch it! Misery: 10/10.

Rob Reiner is one of my favorite directors, and Misery is one of his finest works. I also saw it the day before Halloween, which added to the experience.Misery follows an author named Paul who is severely injured in a car crash during a snowstorm. A nurse takes him in, and claims to be his biggest fan. She seems sweet, especially with her cross necklace, but things are not always as they seem. Not many horror movies scare me, in fact I have no "scariest movie I have ever seen." (The closest I can say is Salo or the 120 Days of Sodom, which is more disgusting than "scary." )Misery does succeed at scares, though. There's a "hobbling" scene, where a man's heels are chopped off. (My Godfather told me that he used to rewind that part over and over.)Many scenes with Annie Wilkes are creepy in fact. You never know what she will do. As a Christian, I was a little bothered that the woman was committing these acts with a cross necklace around her neck-but I just reminded myself that it's just a movie. Gene Siskel said he admired that as irony. I agree, it's just a use of irony.There are many gripping scenes-like the dinner scene. I was upset with how that resulted. I'll let you see the clip for yourself. That's not a complaint, though, it was actually very clever for Reiner to NOT give me what I wanted. Another great scene is when Paul fights Annie. That is also another scary scene that succeeds.I should also note that I can recall all of this, and I saw it 23 months ago! That shows how great it is- I can remember a lot of it, even after under 2 years!Misery is a great horror movie that you should see. Misery really does love company, and you should definitely be a part of it.

Rob Reiner's remarkable adaption of Misery is gripping, twisted, very effectively acted and is without any question one of the best thrillers of all time. Bates and Caan are simply natural stars, as they produce very convincing character personalities. But the gripping routine of the film is stunning and has several highlight scenes that are very exciting and ominous.First of all, the climatic point of this book-based thriller is incredible. It's disturbing, graphic and very shocking, and is also what thriller fans truly desire. But of course the climax is saved until after the film's other sequences of manipulation and uncertainty, in which without giving any spoilers (that need to be avoided for people who haven't seen the movie), which feature very graphically chilling visuals and amazing use of background music.James Caan takes the roll as Paul Sheldon, a successful writer, who is imprisoned by his "number-one" fan, Annie Wilkes, who is played by Kathy Bates. Paul Sheldon is our casual and norm thriller protagonist. He's a spectacular character, but Misery's antagonist is phenomenal. Annie Wilkes is amazingly-produced and extraordinarily-performed.These unique Stephen King characters blend excellently into the finely-formed tale. If it weren't clear enough, Misery is also a really moving and engaging thriller, but is definitely chilling, twisted and disturbing. It's an astonishing storyline targeting a disabled character's struggle to escape the house of his manipulator. Misery isn't directly a horror or scary movie, but is psychologically thrilling, no matter how many times you witness it.If you liked this review, check out the full review and other reviews at aussieboyreviews.

Review title: Bates performance in "Misery" is one of the greatest ever
Review_body: This is one of the few great Stephen King-movies ever. And it is the most un-expected success. I didn't really thought it was possible to make a movie out of the novel, but what do you know, here comes Rob Reiner out of all people with fabolus James Caan and holy Kathy Bates. This movie is very frightening, and it is almost as **scary** as the ultimate Stephen King-movie (and one of the best horrormovies) THE SHINING, but not as great. It is also pretty creepy in a way, since Reiner did MISERY only a year after the fantastic romantic comedy WHEN HARRY MET SALLY... It makes your stomach turn a bit. Now, the big problem with this movie was what I suspected. Length. To make a movie about an invalid author lying in a bed, it can't stretch out to 107 min. Not even in a Kubrick-2001-way. But the savior is Bates. Her performance is one of the strongest and best I've ever seen. It lies very high up in the psycho-list, among Peter Lorre's and Anthony Perkin's performances in M and PSYCHO. Stephen King's novel-based movies should all be banned with the exception of THE SHINING and MISERY.

When I first read the book Misery, I thought it was wonderful and when I found out there was a movie based on it, I couldn't wait to see it. Anyways, Misery is about a writer named Paul Sheldon(James Caan) who gets into a terrible car accident and a crazed fan of his Annie Wilkes(Kathy Bates) saves him and makes him a prisoner in her home. Nobody knows where Paul is and there is no way that Paul can escape with his terribly injured legs. But Annie has other plans for him, she wants him to write a sequel for her favorite character "Misery Chastaine". And Paul better obey her, because Annie is his number one fan and she's never going to let him go now. The movie didn't quite follow the book but I still enjoyed it. In the book, Annie Wilkes was way more crazier and violent which was the main reason that I loved the book. Also the movie missed some of the main events in the book that were totally gruesome and gripping and really showed how crazy Annie was. But overall it was a good movie and a wonderful book. Also Kathy Bates gives a great performance. I would give Misery 6.5/10

Holy cow! I've seen things in my life which have scared the living hell out of me and I have seen things come and go. But I haven't seen such a mad, twisted movie ever. I had heard that it was something to be terrified of, but, hey, I heard the same thing about "The Shining", and it wasn't really so. This time though...it was.SPOILERSI like to write in my free time. I'm young, I'm restless, but I'm peaceful. That means I write. Actually what I write is quite good, not that I'd be bragging now, but I possess potential! Still I'm quite insecure. It's the usual problems: some people encourage you, some people don't. What matters is that the people who you care about do. And I'm not so sure it is that way in my case. So after seeing what "dangers" writing might bring to me, I've started thinking...heh! Fooled you! it's not that dramatic.Kathy Bates is great. I don't know how she managed it, but she gave her character the savageness which was necessary. A two sided person, with a soft and a dangerous part, left alone with a writer, who happens to be the favorite writer of the person. And things happen and things change and it gets all messy and stuff. So there we have a man who is incapable of moving and a woman who is a little bit mentally unbalanced. A hell of an idea.
The movie has some scenes which are almost outrageous. Scary. Very scary. Kathy has her merits and so does mister Caan. On the whole the story is not as deep as I'd like it to be. I feel like it could've gone to more dimensions or something similar. But the scares and the madness compensate. It's at the limit of tolerabilty, so I wouldn't wonder if some people had the exact opposite opinion than me. I consider the movie a well filmed horror and thriller which is a must see for all those interested in the genre. Some great acting performances and the beautiful Stephen King touch. 8/10

Review title: Feels like a cheap TV movie. Stick with the book instead.
Review_body: World famous author Paul Sheldon crashes his car whilst driving in a blizzard but is rescued by nurse and super-fan Annie Wilkes who has read everything he's ever published as well as reading and viewing every interview he's ever given. Sheldon finds himself trapped with multiple injuries included compound fractures to his legs meaning that he is immobile and dependent on Wilkes to care for him. She also tells him that the telephone lines and down and roads closed, both of which are lies. Things take a darker turn still when Wilkes goes and buys the latest book by Sheldon which has just been published (yes the road to town has mysteriously been reopened but there's no mention of Wilkes taking Paul to a local hospital) only to discover that her favourite character Misery has died during childbirth. Wilkes isn't happy about this. This is bad news for Sheldon.Misery explores the obsessive, irrational fan devotion that was explored in very different circumstances in Scorsese's meisterwerk The King of Comedy, a film that bombed at the box office whilst Misery was a huge hit but is inferior in comparison. Oh, the irony.Before seeing Misery for the first time I had read and thoroughly enjoyed Stephen King's masterful novel of the same name. The film adaptation feels like the finer nuances of the novel have been erased to make a big screen shocker that contains great performances by Kathy Bates (Wilkes) and James Caan (Sheldon) with Paul's literary agent being portrayed effortlessly by the ever divine Lauren Bacall.But the film also feels like some kind of TV movie that lacks not just the depth of King's novel but also the cinematic grandeur that might have been envisaged and realised by another director other than Rob Reiner.Misery feels like an attempt to hit big at the box office by creating two dimensional characters and cheap shocks rather than delivering anything with real intelligence. And it worked. Misery brought in the money and earned Bates an Oscar. But watch Misery next to other, better King adaptations such as The Shining and Carrie and you'll see what I mean. There's no comparison.

Review title: Could have been great, ended up just good
Review_body: Stephen King's stories are great cinematic material - there's a couple I can think of in IMDb's Top 250 - and Misery has a similarly strong story. Beneath the storyline, however, I wasn't massively intrigued: the acting felt a bit over-the-top (maybe slightly too retro and 90s for me), and the music was of a similar ilk.All in all, I felt that this film will be remembered more for the story than anything else. Set in the frozen landscape of Colorado's backcountry and following a writer finishing his defining novel, Misery is brilliant at setting a scene. This story is unique in its dynamics, and the acting of Kathy Bates (who won an Oscar for her role) is befittingly scary and unpredictable.Unfortunately, some of stylistic choices are a bit bizarre. Considering the setting, not much of Colorado's scope is used in the film; further to this, some of the "high tension" moments felt forced, sapping a degree of drama from the scenes.I am a big Stephen King fan - I just don't think this was the best adaptation there could have been, and time has not been kind.

I am a big Stephen King fan. I have been ever since I picked up the book night shift. But I gotta say, his stuff never really translates well onto film.First, let me say that I thought the acting was fantastic. Kathy Bates deserved the Oscar! James Caan was also first rate in the movie. The problem with the movie had nothing to do with them. I'm not even sure it had anything to do with the director or producers.It was actually quite hard to figure out what bothered me about this movie (other than the fact that I have no deep seeded need to see someones ankles broken!)until my mom pointed out that Stephen King understands something that a lot of horror/psychological thriller writers seemed to have either forgotten or missed and that is that anything you can imaging is much (bigger, hairier, sharper, just plain scarier) than anything I can show you. Once you put it on the screen, you take the director's view of what's scary shoved at you. If that view isn't one that scares the viewer personally, then the movie misses and the scares are just not there.This movie didn't scare me any more than someone jumping around the corner yelling "boo" at me. It didn't make me think, it didn't disturb me, heck...it didn't even say "boo" that loudly! If you want a REALLY good Stephen King movie, go for Carrie instead.I'm giving this movie out of 10 because the acting was good.

My main problem with this is that I found the film too long for its rather limited subject matter. We see Kathy Bates go from unnatural calm to hysterical rage then back to calm then rage again and so on, all the while James Caan tries to escape. This scheme becomes quickly monotonous. I think a good half hour could have been cut off to the film's advantage.There is a good deal of dark humour in this film and I would have preferred if this aspect had been emphasised in the manner of old Ealing comedies. There are a few scenes late on, particularly the hobbling scene and the gory fight near the end, which I thought to be overly sadistic. Surely these were unnecessary? I understand the book was gorier, however.Overall, watchable but with longueurs.

Review title: Bate's & Caan's acting plus directing at its best!
Review_body: Good old classic suspense film, with awesome and stunning performances with an amazing script and good directing. So entertaining so psycho that you will wanna watch it again with your friends. Good music, good flow not tiring... A total success!

Review title: Subtle Horror Thriller With Profound Results !!!
Review_body: Misery is not just the name of a book character, but a state of mind !Paul Sheldon(James Caan) a writer extraordinaries on his way to the publishers for a review to the conclusion of the "Misery" series books, unexpectedly runs into a snowstorm, and takes a wrong turn that changes HIS life....Rescued by Annie Wilkes(Kathy Bates),who won an Academy award for this part, and is his NUMBER 1 FAN, nurses Paul while he recuperates,and crosses the line between sanity and madness.Annie,a former nurse, with an INTERESTING background, takes Paul into her house where she assaults and further victimizes him, to coerce a final book for the "Misery"series with an ending she prefers.Paul who is barely ambulatory, desperately seeks to escape his tormentor , but is foiled when Annie sees a ceramic "Penguin" rearranged,facing the wrong direction, and realizes Paul must be corrected for the errors of his ways !!!"Hobbling" takes on a whole new application....Directed by Rob Reiner, one of his better works , takes you into the world of Annie Wilkes, a nurse whose background would make Freud scratch his head. She has had a history of being around newborns whose life expectancy has been shortened considerably !The NUMBER 1 FAN of Paul Sheldon, his cross in life to bear, torments and increases his disabilities in order to help him create the ULTIMATE "Misery" book, a nightmare collaboration to say the least !!!Meanwhile, the town Sheriff "Buster" McCain(Richard Farnsworth) is trying to solve the disappearance and stumbles onto Annie and his fate is set !There is a Bittersweet and Tender moment when Annie reveals a softer side for her feelings about Paul, but they are quickly tempered when she pulls an empty revolver from her robe, and we realize how lost and loveless this woman really is...A compelling story , that will send chills up and down your spine, and every celebrity out there, who is wondering , when or where they might run into their NUMBER 1 FAN..!!!???

A seemingly simple movie, with very few characters and not a complex setup, but man, it was a really gripping, thrilling and exciting story. Outstanding acting by Kathy Bates and James Caan. Shows you in an over exaggerated way how obsessed some fans are, and that is how some people are in real life, they sometimes forget about their own lives."Misery" does not go over the top and horror is, you could say mild, but it succeeds to build tension and suspense, since Paul is in such a desperate and by the looks of it, inescapable scenario. This movie sort of over achieves itself, the plot is nothing special, the characters are kind of one-sided, but, in my opinion, Kathy Bates's performance is what really shines here, making this seemingly simple film a true masterpiece.People say it is the greatest movie adaptation of a Stephen King book, which personally i have not read, but that seems to be the case. Bizarre set of coincidences, followed by Paul Sheldon's suspenseful fight to stay alive in the miserable situation he was in. A decent thriller overall, going to be worth your while.

Misery (1990) is an edge of the seat thriller that still holds up very well after 25 years.The film is very basic, Paul(James Caan)is a writer who suffers a car crash in a snow blizzard and is rescued Annie (Kathy Bates) who is a crazy fan. At first she seems like she is taking care of him but things go from bad to worse as she keeps him against his will.The film mainly consists of the two characters in one house (one room mainly) and the tension is nerve shredding. The atmosphere changes in an instance, time and time again. Annie is crazy and does some sick things in order to get what she wants, for Paul to rewrite his novel and finish it the way she wants.When Paul realises how crazy Annie is, the struggle he goes through is gut wrenching. In particular the scene where he finally reaches the telephone only to find out that it will not work because Annie had already planned ahead and disconnected it.The film was done very well, the main element of the story got going almost instantly and after everything was done, the film pretty much ended. The whole film is basically in one location and I just loved the atmosphere it created. A really good edge of your seat thriller.One of my favourite Rob Reiner films along with When Harry Met Sally, Flipped & Stand By Me.

Review:
'Misery' is an American psychological-horror film directed by Rob Reiner. It is based on Stephen King's novel of the same name. It's been a while since I seen this movie and I've got to say that I didn't love it as much as I remember I did. I mean, it's a great claustrophobic thriller with some great performances. It just didn't have the same feel it did when I first watched it years ago.
The plot revolves around a famous writer, Paul Sheldon (James Caan), who gets into a car wreck and is saved and seems to be nursed back to health by a woman, Annie (Kathy Bates) who claims to be his number one fan. After ready a copy of his latest release in his famous 'Misery' book series, and finding out her favorite character was killed, Annie makes Paul write another story to bring her favorite character back to life, while also making his life a living hell.
Everybody talks about Kathy Bates's performance in this movie, and while it is a scary and good take on Annie Wilkes, James Caan is break takingly good as the writer Paul Sheldon. In every helpless scene he is in where he is trying to escape or showing us how much pain, he is in when going in and out of his wheelchair. I was seriously in awe watching him work this character into his own creation.
I love the camera work in this movie. I expected to because it is a Rob Reiner film, but he is so good behind a camera. He uses long and wide shots for extremely simple scenes. By that I mean it could just a be man sitting in the library looking up information and the angle he uses is so beautifully shot. Where the movie lacks is in its scare department. This is supposed to be a horror movie after all or at least a thriller, but where I see it, it's just a drama movie that has intense scenes. That's not to say the movie is bad or anything, just if your going to serve me a slice of lemon pie, make sure I taste the lemon.
Overall, this movie shows that Stephen King is more than just a weird horror author that only writes about creepy monsters or supernatural elements. It still has a feel on a movie he would produce, but with a certain zest added to it.
3.5/5

" Misery " is up there with the best of them , a classic horror that will keep you gripped throughout .This movie is in my special DVD collection, and for a very good reason , it's simply brilliant !!!!!If you have'nt seen it already , Dont wait any longer !!!Kathy Bates delivers an incredible performance as the scary Annie Wilkes, with James Caan as her unfortunate , incapacitated , reluctant guest !!!!!!Thrilling from start to finish , it's captivating !A faultless masterpiece , from the pen of the genius that is Stephen King !
