Review title: One of the best thrillers of the 90's.
Review_body: Misery is without a doubt one of the finest movies of the 90's and one of the best movies in the thriller genre. It is an ingeniously crafted horror masterpiece that seamlessly intertwines its incredibly tense and cleverly paced story with inventive cinematography, tight editing and exquisite performances. In my opinion Misery is one of the better adaptations of Stephen King's works and truly a movie that cannot be missed, especially for the genre fans.Paul Sheldon (James Caan) is the author of a successful series of romance novels about a character called Misery, who decides to take a more serious approach regarding his future novels. On his way to publish his new manuscript, Paul drives from his hotel in Silver Creek to New York. Due to the extreme weather conditions, he has an accident that leaves him severely injured and hopeless. A local nurse named Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates) finds Paul and brings him to her remote home in order to help him recover. Claiming to be his number one fan, Annie discovers that in his last Misery novel her favorite character dies and then her obsession about him takes a dark and twisted turn as a long story of captivity and abuse begins.The direction by Rob Reiner is phenomenal and on a Hitchcockian level as the film has a plethora of perfectly crafted suspenseful moments that have the audience on the edge of their seats from the beginning till the amazing climax. The editing of the movie is also flawless, as the shots are specifically designed to induce tension in any moment they can. The cinematographer and Reiner both ace the perilous atmosphere of the picture, using close up shots of the moonfaced Wilkes both in her fits of rage and kindness which magnifies the polar extremes that Wilkes is prone to unexpectedly visit. What is also triumphed is the slow convergence of the audience and Paul Sheldon. The movie received a lot of critical acclaim, especially due to Kathy Bates' chilling and memorable performance as Anny Wilkes that earned her the 1990's leading actress Oscar award, which remains the only Oscar ever given to a Stephen King film adaptation. No matter how great Kathy Bates' Oscar-winning performance is, James Caan's cannot go unnoticed as it definitely qualifies as one of the best performances in his extensive career, despite how demanding and challenging his role as Paul Sheldon was.In conclusion, Misery is a dark and tense masterpiece that is an amalgamation of excellent direction, skillful writing, taut editing, amazing cinematography and stellar performances, which succeeds into creating the feeling of captivity and helplessness that the thriller genre was purposefully built for, and that makes it one of the best movies of the 90's and one absolute classic in its genre.

Review title: Adrenaline ride from start to finish!
Review_body: James Caan stars as author Paul Sheldon who has made a good living writing romantic novels based around the character Misery Chastaine.However, fearful of being type-cast and tired of continuing the whole Misery saga, he pens his last ever "Misery" novel, hands his manuscript to his publisher and retreats to a remote cabin to write a more gritty novel about slum kids.Once completed, he tucks his manuscript into his trusty old leather wallet, checks out and begins his car journey back to New York - home of his daughter and his publisher. However, a recent blizzard causes Paul to lose control of his car and he subsequently rolls it off the road and down a snowy embankment, sustaining multiple injuries as well as knocking himself unconscious.We, the viewer, witness a passer-by free Paul from the mangled car with a crow bar and carry him off by way of a fireman's lift. We are given no clues as to the identity nor sex of the rescuer.All this occurs in the opening scenes but the real story gets going as Paul awakes in a strange room, slightly concussed and also confused as a strange, rotund woman comes into focus, declaring herself to be his "Number one fan". She also declares herself to be a nurse but, due to the blizzard, she declares the roads to be closed and the phone lines down, making it impossible for an ambulance to get to her remote farm...In spite of carer Annie Wilkes' inventiveness in stabilising Paul's legs via home made splints, she has a presumably illegal stash of various meds and equipment that she has hoarded since her days as a paediatric nurse.Very soon into Paul's incarceration, he allows Annie to read his new manuscript - something he has previously never allowed due to his superstitions but makes an exception due to his acceptance that she saved his life. Upon reading a few chapters, Annie returns to Paul's room with lunch and, when asked for her opinion, she quickly becomes irate about the profanity within. So much so that she launches into a verbal faux pas whilst consistently spilling hot soup all over her victim and subsequently holding him culpable. Realising she's gone too far, she attempts to redeem herself by apologising and thereafter telling Paul that she loves him, before adding 'Your mind, that's all I meant' Almost at once, Paul realises he is in the company of a sociopath and from that point on he plays to her tune in a bid to make good his escape.But escape is never easy when one has broken bones and when he shows signs of recovery he is disabled once again...

Review title: A good thriller, Stephen King's book was better
Review_body: This was an amazing movie don't get me wrong, but it just wasn't scary. I still think it is great but was not as good as the book(same with The Shining,Carrie,Pet Semetary,and It(haven't read any others, just started Salems' Lot)).****Spoilers****The book has more 'horror' in it then the movie,though Stephen King does not try to be scary but thrilling. For example, instead of the *sheriff* getting *shot* in the *basement*. A *deputy* is run over with a *lawn mower* in the *front yard*. Also, the book Paul wrote/Annie made him burn did not have a title, but in the book it was 'Fast Cars'.AND(last one i could find(e-mail me if u find others))instead of having his *ankels broken* with a *sludge hammer* for the hobbling. His foot(left i believe) is *cut off* with an *axe*.****End of Spoilers****The acting of Kathy Bates is amazing because of how she can go from "OOHHHHHH I just bought the first edition of Miserys' Child!" to "You dirty bird...YOU KILLED MISERY*shakes bed*, I Don't WANT HER SPIRIT, I WANT HER!" is amazing. Although Kathy has done great acting in some of my other favorites(Waterboy("Did someone hurt you boy*picks up butchers knife*you just tell momma who hurt you")).This movie has it's ups and downs, at points it has you dragging and bored but then a couple minutes(give it about 10-25)and Kathy Bates will come in as mean as possible creating one of the most feared and infamous 'horror'(more like suspense)character ever.Like Carrie you have to respect the stuff that's going on and look at the thrilling suspense stuff then complaining because it isn't scary and drags you at points until it gets good. 8/10

Wow. After not having seen the film in a while, last week my girlfriend and I, pulled it out and watched it on a rainy, stormy night.Misery is an excellent film, based on King's novel. Since watching the film again, I went to my bookshelf, and reread the novel in three nights. I'll tell you one thing. I'll take the movie Annie over the novel Annie, if I was in that situation. If you haven't read the novel, I suggest you do. In the movie, there are times when Annie Wilkes is quite likable. But not so in the novel.The movie is a great suspense film, greatly acted by Kathy Bates and James Caan. You can actually put yourself in Paul Sheldon's shoes, and picture it being you. At times you want to yell at the screen and say, "Paul, don't say that. You're gonna make her mad." This poor man, totally disabled and at the mercy of the insane Annie. I read that James Caan said this was one of his toughest roles to play, because he was in bed or a wheelchair through the whole film. He went stir crazy. That probably helped him with his performance.These are some of the things that were not shown, and toned down in the film. The film never shows that Annie got Paul addicted to pain killers. She made him drink dirty dishwater to swallow his pills. In the film, the hobbling scene is quite horrid. But in the novel, he not only loses his foot with an axe, but other things as well. I won't ruin it. There are other things not depicted in the film, like Annie leaving Paul for fifty hours, forcing him to drink his own urine. Like I said, I'd take the Annie from the film over the novel Annie, without a doubt.The movie stays suspenseful because you feel so bad for this man. He's helpless. The only person keeping him alive, is a sick, twisted, f***, to use Paul's words. Annie Wilkes reminds me of a kid that likes to light kittens on fire, or tear the wings off butterflies. But always telling Paul she loves him, and it's for his own good.When I saw the film in the theater in 1990, the audience cheered for Paul at the end. My girlfriend and I cheered once again last week. "You remember how nobody ever knew who Misery's father was, and if they'd ever be reunited?" "Paul, you can't." "Why not, I learned it from you." CLASSIC SCENE.Well, I guess this isn't a review. Just ramblings on my thoughts of this great film. If you haven't seen it, see it. If you haven't seen it in a while, curl up on a creepy night, and watch it again. And if you really want to get scared, read the novel....Sincerely, Vincent "What's the matter? I'll tell you what's the matter. I go out of my way for you. And what do I get? You bought the wrong paper, Annie. I can't write on this paper, Annie. Well you better start showing me a little more respect around here, MISTER MAN."

Review title: This movie is brilliant and brutal.
Review_body: So after a lot of years of watching horror movies and loving horror movie adaptations of Stephen king books, i realised i had never watched Misery, after watching it i realised i should have took the time to watch it many years ago.The story is about a writer who having finished a book decides to return home, but on his return he has a accident and is rescued by his number one fan after that things take a dark twist while he is trying to recover from the accident, the story in this film is brilliant and gripping, you are always on edge of your seat wanting the main character to succeed its very believable which makes you fully emerged in the film.The acting in this is brilliant and makes this film stand out, James Caan and Kathy bates are so believable, you genuinely hate but want to understand Kathy Bates's character and you are constantly behind James Caans character wanting him to succeed.A great movies for horror and Thriller fans, Worth a watch to anyone who's interested in either genre.

Review title: An intensely frightening and believable story
Review_body: Set during the cold winter in Colorado; bestselling author, Paul Sheldon (James Caan) has just finished writing his final Misery novel. A series of novels about a woman n the 19th  Misery Chastain. On his way back to New York, he is caught up in a blizzard and crashes. Luckily he is saved by Annie Wilkes (The versatile Kathy Bates), who takes him back to her isolated cottage in the icy mountains, where she nurses him back to health. Unfortunately, Annie just happens to be Paul's 'number one fan' and upon discovering this is Misery's final novel, she reveals her instability  before imprisoning him and terrorizing him  Kathy Bates is as many people have already said  the star. Ignorantly, I'd only seen her in the famous 'Titanic' where she played a rich and upper-class American widow; here is a much better role. Where plays an obsessed psycho; but carefully conceals her psychotic side under a cloak of innocence and nice. She very rightfully deserved the award for Best Actress in a Leading Role she claimed later in 1991. James Caan, who I'd actually never heard of, is also excellent as the imprisoned writer. Richard Farnsworth and Frances Sternhagen add a small, undisruptive comical side to the story as the bickering husband and wife/Sheriff and Deputy who are meanwhile trying to find Paul  who is missing form their perspective. Lauren Bacall gives a nicely acted cameo as Marcia Sindell  Paul's editor who appears at the very beginning and in the final scene.Those who are expecting a climatic horror  I'm afraid you'll be disappointed. But don't be put off. What makes Misery so scary and unsettling is that the viewers have absolutely no idea what the deranged Annie Wilkes is going to do next. And I can promise you will be trembling in your seats whenever she is on screen.What I also liked about Misery is that there aren't many characters; which is helpful as you are completely focused on the plot without being distracted by the large amount of people. The majority of the film is just Paul and Annie alone in the cottage; with the occasional glimpse at the Sheriff and his wife  who are looking for him.The script was well written  all down to William Goldman. One of my favorite script writers  I also recommend 'The Stepford Wives' (1975) to anyone who hasn't already seen it  another Goldman success.I first saw Misery on channel four, back in November; which I recorded over and bought the DVD. I strongly advise you to do the same, for there are a number of special features on which is always good, as Misery is nearly 16 years old. These features include interviews from Kathy Bates, James Caan, William Goldman and Rob Reiner and information on the musical that Misery inspired.So, in summary Kathy Bates is superb; as are the entire cast  from James Caan to Lauren Bacall. But, the backstage cast are equally good especially the director and screen writer. Which as I've learnt recently; is just as important. Another successful adaptation from Stephen King. I'd also recommend 'Carrie' and 'Secret Window'  two other excellent screen versions.A first-rate thriller entwined with an excellent horror.

Would See It Again - A popular romance novelist crashes his car in a blizzard, but is luckily saved by homely nurse Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates, Waterboy's Mom). She is his self-proclaimed number one fan, which he laughs off at first but soon discovers to be eerily true. As she nurses him back to health in her snowbound house, she discovers that the next book in her beloved Misery series (which he writes) is the last. The pure greatness of this film comes from her shift from caring adoring fan to psychotic captor. Kathy Bates won an extremely deserved Academy award for her role. I mean she's just REALLY CREEPY. But there's a sincerity there that made the character semi-identifiable, as opposed to out-and-out psycho. "You can't possibly understand how scared someone like me is of losing someone like you." James Caan, the trapped author, also does a good job with his role, and though sitting on his ass is his main job, you really felt his pain and torture (both literally and figuratively) in his hellish prison. The ingenuity of his attempted escapes was also pretty cool, though we all assume MacGyver would have been out of there the first night. There was a good bit of comic relief sprinkled in too. As Rob Reiner he is not a horror director, the feel to this movie is focused on the story and the characters, not constantly building up tension with dark and scary camera angles. All together, it's a very well written, very well acted and very well directed movie that is incredibly enjoyable and definitely worth seeing.

Excellent acting in this very suspenseful movie.
It keeps you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end.

Review title: Quite possibly the best horror movie ever made.
Review_body: Rob Reiner, Kathy Bates, James Caan, and Stephen King.  This is a cinematic match made in heaven.James Caan doesn't get enough credit for his Portrayal of Paul Sheldon.  He was brilliant in my estimation.  His range of facial expressions taking the place of the internal dialogue that existed for his character in the book. He was definitely sympathetic enough to make us really care about what happened to him, which is what any good horror movie needs.Kathy Bates' performance was simply a tour de force.  She was just perfectly cast.  And she was masterful in her execution as the ultimate villain; a monster that seriously COULD be living right next door.  She demonstrates a common theme for Stephen King: That real monsters don't have tails and fangs and horns, but are instead regular people that we allow to get close to use who either are or become insane.Rob Reiner just proves that he is one of the best directors in the business, and that he can cross genres with aplomb.  I think it is interesting that two of his best are Stephen King adaptations, this movie (Misery) and Stand By Me.If you want to really be chilled to the bone, see this movie.9/10

Misery is one of my favorite novels. This movie is very faithful to the book and has the exact same level of suspense. Misery is meant to be a horror story for writers, like (if you hadn't already by my screen name) me. Writers always fear what would happen if they suddenly changed what their writing. It's the readers that the writer is worried about. This novel/movie plays on that fear. Paul Sheldon, the main character, decides to write another novel that's very different from what he's written (The "Misery" series, I assume it's a romance series oddly enough). So he writes the last "Misery" novel (honestly, that's the worst name to give to a woman) and kills the main character off. The crap hits the fan when he's rescued by a stalker-like woman who LOVES (literally) him from a car crash in Colorado. If you're a writer, read the novel first then see the movie. The movie does a pretty good job and is very faithful. They watered down the movie, but why does it matter? It still is very faithful! Read the novel and see the movie. I dare you...

Review title: Good Movie but could have been much more.
Review_body: It is not at all a bad movie. Both Kathy Bates and James Caan delivered. But for a thriller movie based on a Stephen King book it came nowhere close to the novel. Anne Wilkes from the book connects with us more than the one in the movie. Kathy Bates for me, was a bit too natural in many scenes. That might be because she's a good actress (she got an Academy award for the role after all) but I felt that a bit more exaggeration might have actually helped this character more.The characters in the book told us many things - the rage and emotions felt by Paul as a writer, the level of Anne's insanity (conveyed beautifully through her past) and above all the agony of an accident victim. The movie was in a kind of "run through every emotions as quickly as possible" mode. Especially in the "agony" part. The 'wounded' wasn't that wounded in the movie.So in short, the movie is worth watching but if you've read the book then you might be left with that unsatisfactory feeling at the end.

Review title: When you treat your audience like idiots
Review_body: The movie started off nicely, but when it got to the part where the sheriff is reading the books in bed and then decides to write down a quotation from it on a piece of paper, and then later goes to look at some newspaper archives and opens a volume to some random page and finds the exact quote, you know that the film producers think the audience is a bunch of imbiciles to buy that. Amazing how a fillm with that kind of stupidity can get such high ratings is beyond me. Oh, and let's not forget about the moment before he goes to the news archives that the woman almost hits a car right in front of him while he's sitting in the office.Sorry, but if this was from Stephen King, it is truly one of his dumbest works. No comparison to The Shawshank Redemption.

This film demonstrates what little is needed to create gut-wrenching suspense - just with two characters stuck in a house, this story will totally absorb you, terrify you, and have you dripping with perspiration in a way that the modern explosive action movie could only hope to achieve.As with all the best Rob Reiner films, you get a very polished product - careful direction, including cinematography and music, and flawless acting. Kathy Bates is up there with Hopkins' Lecter and Joe Pesci's evil gangster characters in her portrayal of Annie Wilkes - a cross between the sweetest nurse you could ever imagine, and Satan.Reiner and screenwriter Goldman crank up the suspense with skill, pushing it as far as possible while keeping things plausible, so that by the time you reach the 'hobbling' scene you are going to undergo one of the most harrowing experiences of your life. This is an awesome, powerful piece of entertainment and a true modern classic.

The first time I watched this movie, I wasn't all that impressed. I mean, I thought it was good, but I didn't truly appreciate the film until subsequent viewings.James Caan plays the part of novelist Paul Sheldon, whose books include a series of novels with the character named "Misery". Paul is driving in his car one very snowing evening in Colorado, when his car slides out of control and flips off the side of the road. We see him being rescued by a person who turns out to be Annie Wilkes, played by Kathy Bates. She brings him back to health at her house in the wilderness, always proclaiming to be Paul's "#1 Fan". We can tell something's definitely wrong with Annie right with the first few encounters with Paul, as she's definitely someone who's possessing a wee bit too much fanaticism with the novelist. Eventually, she forces Paul to write a new novel in the Misery series, keeping him under lock and key, not allowing him to leave, even after his injuries have sufficiently healed. In fact, in a possessive rage, she injures him even further, in one of the most grotesque on-screen injuries I've ever witnessed.I'll stop right there and not reveal anything further about the plot. It needs to be seen to really be appreciated. But what really needs to be appreciated is the acting ability of Kathy Bates. Watching scenes of her persona go from admiration of Paul, to quickly turning into rage through the help of psychosis, is something to behold. She really makes it believable. I said her moods turn quickly, but only in the sense of being in the same scene. Just watching her facial reactions turn slowly during these times, are not only truly believable and scary, but they are also the mark of a great actor. Under the direction of Rob Reiner, she pulls these scenes off flawlessly, and it's a beauty to see.James Caan is very good in his own right, but Kathy Bates steals this show. It's kind of a throwback to the great actors from the past, who can make you feel sympathy to vindictiveness in one scene.A Must See!!!

This is definitely one of my favorite suspense type films ever. I mean...as soon as you seen Kathy Bates, you know s**t is about to go down. This is classic Kathy! This movie keeps you on your toes as you go through this adventure. Definitely worth a watch. Classic!
Camerawork not the best, storyline easy to follow, actors are amazing and the storyline is psychoticWatch if you aren't scared of anything cause this will scare you!

Review title: King ditches the supernatural and gives us real life horror.
Review_body:
After a long history about dealing with the supernatural horror with haunted hotels, resurrected murderous kids, telekinetic prom queens, possesed cars and killer clowns from other dimensions, we get from the master of Horror a heavily isolated movie that's scarier than all things mentioned above.When we think of survival horror we often think in zombie movies or post apocaliptic films in which the character have to survive a force of great evil. This one whoever fits in the genre in the most unusual of ways, isolating the protagonist in a cabin inside the a situation that is almost ironically funny, and making the evil force a psychotic nurse in whose our main lead's life depends.Is a thrill ride from start to finish that only gets heartbumping every minute.
We cannot ignore Kathy Bates's amazing performance as the emotionally unstable Annie Wilkes. From the moment she is on screen we learn that something is not right with her, is then when the film starts pumping when we know she can jump from loving careful mother to murderous psychopath displaying a master class in acting.Thrilling and unsettlingly realistic.

Sometimes a film is remembered for a single performance, or for a particularly memorable moment, or for the expertly crafted score. For me, Misery ticks all those boxes and more. It's one of the most underrated thrillers, and movies, of the 1990's, packed with great dialogue, interesting shots and a killer ending. Rob Reiner's magnum opus, I'd go as far as saying. Some would argue it edges slightly too far away from the source material by Stephen King, but as I haven't read it, I'm going to judge solely on what I've seen, and William Goldman's script is brilliant.I could write for hours about Kathy Bates in the role of Annie Wilkes, but I'll endeavour to be succinct. It's a big, bold, brave performance that occasionally veers towards the more animated, but never, not for a single moment, loses its core of truth. Many other actresses would have toned it down, made Annie quieter and more inwardly intimidating, but the film would have been poorer for that. James Caan, usually the epitome of charisma, is more restrained here, physically and emotionally, which allows for Bates to really go for it. The result is, in my opinion, one of the most unpredictable and fascinating performances in film.There's a creeping sense of dread running through Misery from the beginning, though it's occasionally pierced with dark and often cheeky humour, almost used to disarm us. The camera shows things from everyone else's point of view, rarely, if ever, from Annie's, adding to that growing feeling of unease and making the whole thing so watchable. Makes you wonder what she'll do next. There are a lot of scenes inside the Wilkes house, but there are some beautiful and picturesque shots of the surroundings and nearby town, as well as Paul's agents office in the city, much needed to break that earlier referenced claustrophobia.The first ten minutes will hook you in, and the last ten will wear you out. As for all the bits in between, well... your ankles might jump a bit, you'll find new meaning to the phrase "number one fan" and you'll witness one of cinema's most captivating and disturbed characters come to life.

Review title: Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde is right. Spoilers.
Review_body: When doctor Paul Sheldon takes a ride home, he didn't imagine in his wildest dreams that he would be taken captive by a woman whose whole persona changed at the drop of a hat. All seems well at first, although the audience does wonder whether Paul is as injured as he seemed to be at the crash site. His legs seemed to look worse than they should have been.Soon she begins to inquire about his recent book and even goes out to purchase a copy. She shows her true colours and flies into a rage upon discovering that Misery Chastain is dead. She goes as far as to nearly hit him in the head with a chair. Annie then claims to have not told anyone about his whereabouts. Without her, he will not survive. This film is an example of a good script, great talents and directing coming together. It is a film you will be able to re-watch throughout your life. James Caan is very believable in his role as a man held captive by a raving lunatic who has killed babies in the past. Kathy Bates has not been given enough films. Her portrayal of Annie Wilkes will leave you wondering whether she is like that in reality!A true interpretation of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde. She is a truly underrated actress who has not been appreciated enough. A true thrilling classic!

I was honestly scared in the beginning because it was started off slow, but then things grew intense exponentially. Then things grew even more exponentially. And then the line of the graph reached a vertical undefined slope. This film doesn't have many jumpscares, but it has so much in the creepy level. Kathy Bates did an excellent job playing her character. There's no doubt that a Stephen King based movie would be excellent to watch.
I did not find the acting to be particularly good. paul could have been played by anyone, and annie was pretty stilted. a movie where nothing much goes on

oh my god!! this movie goes in my top 10. the film is about james caan, a writer, being captured by a crazed fan played by kathy bates. the film is very well directed, which i recently found out it was directed by Rob Reiner, which i think in anyone elses hands this movie could be an absolute mess, but he pulls it off.The main reason this movie is so terrific, is Kathy Bates, she plays Annie Wilkes, probably one of the most complex characters in film. She won a well-deserved Oscar for this role and she should have. Her performance is great on so many levels, and after seeing her in this mad me appreciate the film twice as much. Great directing, great performances, great film!! don't' even bother renting it, just go out and buy the DVD

Review title: Disappointing when compared to the book
Review_body: Well, I went into this movie after having read the book, and I can say that this movie doesn't even hold a candle to what the book is.... both objectively and subjectively.This movie is a pretty straightforward, linear thriller. The book is so, so, SO much more than that with layers of depth to it and a much more coherent and gripping story.However, I can appreciate this film for what it is. I think that if I had seen this movie prior to reading the book, or maybe even seen it when I was younger, I would have liked it much more than I do now. The acting in this movie is very solid, especially Kathy Bates' performance. James Caan did very well also, for what he had to work with.Overall I don't think this is a bad movie at all... but I think most reviews on here giving this movie 8-10 star ratings are from people who haven't read the book... I will admit I didn't enjoy this movie that much for that reason alone. There are also many differences between the two, and I can't knock the movie too much for it considering I understand some of the challenges they faced in adapting it to the big screen.One brief thing I wanted to mention, is I didn't like the soundtrack to this movie. I feel like a soundtrack can sometimes make or break a movie. While it doesn't go either way in this case, it closely leans towards the "break" side for me. The soundtrack is just too intrusive and hasn't aged well.In summary this movie was okay and I can see why it's a cult classic. Had I watched this years ago before I ever read the book I probably would have liked it much, much more than I do now. As it is, I give this movie 5 / 10 stars. Not bad, but do yourself a favor and pick up the book. To simply say it's better is a wild understatement.

I watched Misery in dark, rainy night. And I couldn't sleep after watching it. The image of Annie Wilkes just stuck in my head all the time! She's so scary ( I wish I would never have such a "number-one" fan like her). Kathy Bates definitely deserved her Oscar for bringing us one of the most scary movie villains of the century. Caan and Fansworth did a great job in their roles, too. And we cannot forget Rob Reiner, the talented director who made this movie more than a thriller. Every scene of the film is very exciting and thrill. I like the ending, although there's some blood, which I don't really like to see in a thriller. On the whole, this is a very good film. I recommend this to everyone who loves watching something scary at night. And remember to close your eyes...

Review title: Tense thriller, simple plot, well acted.
Review_body: Love this movie and I've watched it a handful of times over the years. Set in a rural upstate snowy mountain town, writer Paul Sheldon finishes work on his latest novel. When leaving his cabin, a storm catches up and he wrecks flying over the edge of a mountain pass burying his car in the snow and immobilizing him. Local resident Annie Wilkes rescues him and he wakes up in her house on a farm. Annie seems very nice and is an unabashed fan of his but slowly her obsessive and unstable side appears after she has read a draft of his latest novel. Paul is unable to really get around. It really gets interesting once he makes several attempts to escape or incapacitate Wilkes. My only real critique is how Sheriff Buster connects the dots to Wilkes holding him captive or at least suspicion of this. There also could have been some added depth and not an 18-month lapse after he finally overcomes Wilkes capture. Still, a top-notch thriller and a great watch during the winter months!

Review title: Now that's how you do a thriller!
Review_body: I have long held the belief that most, if not all, of Stephen King's stories start out in his mind as 'what if' scenarios, we all have them, but King takes things to the most extreme conclusions possible and scares the daylights out of us in so doing. With 'Misery', he has given us a story so close to autobiographical horror that you could be forgiven for being duped into thinking it actually happened to him.Paul Sheldon is a talented writer who has been bashing out trashy pulp romances which take place in the early 1900's involving a woman named Misery Chastain. They are wildly successful novels which amass him a fortune, facilitate sending his daughter to the best schools and all the other luxuries that a writer of such success enjoys. But he feels as though he has sold out, he has a burning urge to publish his 'real' book and to be taken more seriously, and in this adaptation of King's novel, we are introduced to him as he finishes his opus while holed up in a remote cabin in Colorado. He then attempts to navigate his car through a blizzard and ends up skidding off the road and landing on a snowy bank, upside down. A figure appears and carries him out of the snowed in vehicle. This figure, we soon learn, is Annie Wilkes, and she is his self-proclaimed 'number one fan'. She also happens to be a nurse, and begins the long process of treating his injuries and nursing him back to health in her home. She tells him she has called a doctor and been given what seems fairly reasonable advice about keeping him there until the weather clears if she is able to take care of him herself. I assure you that sharing these plot details gives nothing away, they are merely set-up for the very dark path the story goes down.It turns out that Annie is not entirely of sound mind, and that is almost certainly an understatement. She comes home one day with the latest of his 'Misery' novels and when she discovers that he has killed her off, well, let's just say she is not a little annoyed! I can give no more of the plot away, save to say that this is a thriller of the highest order, and the way Annie's psychosis reveals is performed by Kathy Bates with such masterful skill that she quite literally disappears into the role.Rob Reiner, whose credits include 'The Princess Bride', 'This is Spinal Tap' and King's own 'Stand by Me', at first seems a strange director to helm a horror adaptation, but I rush to assure you he has crafted an incredibly effective thriller. He seems quite at home creating scenes of almost unbearable suspense, but this is not solely to his credit. The casting here is sublime. I have never seen anything Kathy Bates has appeared in, and I believe my lack of knowledge of her work only enhanced my complete belief in her characters state of mind. Other viewers may not be so lucky. There are playful scenes at the beginning of the film which hint that she may not be the full ticket, but then, quite suddenly, we are in no doubt: This woman is completely unhinged. Although some who have read the novel may feel that some of the more horrifying things she does to Sheldon have been watered down a bit, I thought the changes worked here. James Caan, who Reiner coaxed out of retirement and has spent virtually his entire career playing tough, virile and energetic characters, spends almost the entire running time of this film in bed. The dichotomy of having such a physical actor playing a helpless victim is absolutely inspired, and he carries his weight right along with Bates. The cat and mouse chemistry between these two is nothing short of fantastic. These are performers at the top of their game. The supporting cast is rounded out by fine actors too. Richard Farnsworth and the criminally underused Frances Sternhagen play the aging local sheriff and his plucky wife, and we are treated to Lauren Bacall as Sheldon's agent, who is dignity itself.A thrilling story by Stephen King, adapted screenplay by William Goldman, direction by Rob Reiner, performers of the highest standard, and a massively effective score all add up to one of the most suspenseful and effective horror-thrillers of recent years. Have fun, I did.

Review title: "He didn't get out of the COCKADOODIE CAR!"
Review_body: Paul Sheldon is a very successful author for creating the 19th century novels called 'Misery', after completing his final 'Misery' book he heads back home to New York until his car steers off road and crashes in the mountains, due to the weather conditions. As luck would have it, someone is there to the rescue Paul from the wreckage... and his book!.Paul wakes up from being unconscious and finds himself resting in a bed in Annie Wilkes's home. "I'm your number one fan!"Annie Wilkes, an obsessed Paul Sheldon fanatic who loves his novels, has the great pleasure of having him in her home.Annie has the chance of reading Paul's brand new draft of 'Misery', until she's the critic, by wanting what she wants Paul realises throughout the weeks Annie isn't just an ex-nurse but that he's being taken care of by a violent-tempered-psycho. Missing for weeks, presumed dead, Paul thinks of all the possible ways to escape. Whereas he used to write for a living he's now writing to stay alive.Brilliantly portrayed by James Caan and Kathy Bates, this makes Stephen King's best!!!

Review title: A brilliant Thriller-Brilliantly Cast-Brilliantly Acted-Brilliantly Directed-based on a Steven King masterpiece...need i say more!?
Review_body: Once again, a brilliant Novel from the legend that is Mr Steven King. I feel this film version really does do justice to Mr Kings work. The director has brought the novel to life, and has created an extremely thrilling and entertaining film. He also did extremely well with regards to casting Kathy Bates as the freakish and obsessed 'Annie Wilkes' You couldn't find anyone else who could of done the job (and fitted the role) even half as good as Kathy did! Brilliant. In fact, i think all the actors fro the other characters were perfectly cast for this classic film. There's not much more i can say-that other haven't already put...Except i strongly recommend you watch this film if your into thrillers. One or two disturbing scenes (one in particular), so be warned! The film is directed brilliantly with a great screenplay based on yet another Steven King masterpiece. There is really good character development throughout the film-and you actually feel for main character 'Paul Sheldon' as he is held, helpless by his 'number 1' obsessed fan 'Annie Wilkes' If you haven't seen this yet...get a copy. You will enjoy it-if you like Steven King/ a good thriller/ Brilliant acting and good work by the director. Fantastic for those rainy/Snowy!nights in! A must for any collection!8/10

Review title: Paul Sheldon never asked for this Annie
Review_body: Misery is a horror, thriller and is a film very remotely similar to that of Alfred Hitchcock 1960 Psycho. The story follows Paul Sheldon, a successful writer off of his collection of books that goes by the name of Misery. After he had completed a copy of the final edition to the franchise he meets an unfortunate event in which he goes off the main road and crashes his car on the way to work. After the incident he got saved by Annie, his number 1 fan, which at first seemed like everything was going to comeback to normal once she gets him to the hospital. However what he doesn't know coming for hims is that Annie is someone who is totally obsessed with his Misery books, and wasn't going to have him get off so easily unless he concludes the series her way. Mean while, well all of this is happening, detective Buster has been notified by Paul boss about his recent absents, having him go out on the search.The majority of the film took place in one location which is Annie's house and was mainly told from Paul perspective. There will be cuts to Annie getting into a store or to the detective searching for Paul but other than that the audience is basically in the mind of Paul. This makes for an interesting premise since the main protagonist is helpless and there could always be fatal consequences if he doesn't escape or write the story to her liking.The one who carries this movie of course is Kathy Bates which can be seen by her Oscar win. What makes her performances so special is that, she was able to escalate her emotions from a calm and inviting person to full of agony and resentment when her character is proven wrong. James Caan is also great as the backbone of the narrative in which he was required to act as two different people in one character, a reactionary role, and a role where he has to pretend to like Annie. The reactionary road is harder than it looks in this particular story because it collides with him pretending to show affection to Annie. If he shows a lot of anger while not being able to take her on his own than he would risk getting hurt which James kept a good balance of.Overall I rate this film an 8/10 because although it has a neat premise, and a great main protagonist along with antagonist, I feel that the side characters don't add a whole lot to the story. There were times when the detective was given multiple chances to do the right thing but the writers had him not which was to obviously expand the runtime of the film. However this is a much watch film, even if you are not a horror fan!

Having read the book--one of King's finest and most chilling--I was a bit disappointed in the movie.  It changed quite a few things, such as involving this "Buster" guy in the search, and couldn't convey the psychological edge that made the book so spine-tingling: for example, Paul's dependence on Novril, and Annie's eruptions could've been done better by Bates.  Plus the way the novel ends is a bit different and less gruesome than the book.  I suggest you read the book, and see the differences yourself.  But overall, a movie worth watching, just not as good as it could be.

this is by far rob reiners best film of all time. Kathy bates gave an exillerating performance, and did deserve the acamedy award for best actress. I was very suprised when it was not nominated for the best picture award. The film itself is disturbing, especially the hobbling scene, where James Cann get feet sledge hammered into the opposite direction. I object to the 18 age rating in England as the film itself is disturbing but not that violent.A brilliant movie.9/10 this is the best!!!!!!!

This is the best adaptation of a Stephen King novel that I've seen.  I saw the movie before I read the book, and the book wasn't confusing, which it usually seems to be with King if you see the movie first.    This movie holds true to the book very well.  There are some slight differences, and I think the book goes much deeper into Annie's psychosis, which I enjoyed more, but these things don't detract from the general quality of the movie. I liked this movie a lot.

Review title: Kathy Bates+ James Caan= A Great Horror Film ( contains spoilers)
Review_body: The movie is great, there is no other way to describe it. It is about a writer who crashes his car and a crazed fan finds him. She takes care of him, like a normal person, but healing time and resting are not in the picture. She turns violent. Hits him, tortures him so badly. He tries to escape but she always finds out that he tried. Since, he is retiring from writing, his last book, misery (title) dies. She does not like it. She makes him write another one, and Sooner or Later an old cop is murdered by her and she eventually dies. So if you want more. Watch the film.I love this movie so much. Kathy bates gives a Oscar winning performance and James Caan, the perfect victim. The movie adds up and has twists and turns. the perfect movie. SO PERFECT!!!10/10

Review title: Creating such intense tension with one house, two persons is extraordinary!
Review_body: This thriller is really one that never gives you a calm moment untill it´s over, and even not then, when you think about it! The two actors are great, Kathy Bates is really fitting into this role, she is tottaly amazing! In this one, everything is well thought out, there are no misstakes like in the film Dead Calm for example. This is very exiting, a thriller at the top, Hitchcock would not have been ashamed of it!

Review title: Not a patch on the book.
Review_body: The two main actors try their best but the script lacking the grippjng tension of the book and the depth of the characters.This film is far too shallow and one-dimensional and no where near as good as I remember it as a kid.

Review title: Perfect adaptation of the book by Stephen King
Review_body: Astonishing performances by Kathy Bates and James Caan.Paul Sheldon(James Caan) is a writer, he gets in a car accident and is aided by Annie Wilkes who claims to be his number one fan. She takes him to her house and cares for him. Over time she becomes obsessed with him and forces him to bring her favorite character of the books to life.

It's no doubt King was thinking of himself when he wrote the novel, perhaps some deranged fan hopes to have him in the same situation one day. (What a strange situation that would be.) The best part behind this movie is that it is an adaption of one of the very few King novels that deals strictly with humans, (meaning it doesn't include demons or the undead) some of whom seem to be a little crazy. This movie takes the worst possible situation anyone can think of, and somehow makes it worse. Bates won a well-deserved Oscar, but I think it should have been nominated for adapted screenplay as well.

Review title: Good, but it could have been a lot better
Review_body: I had mixed emotions about Misery, on the one hand, I thought that Misery was a good adaptation of the Stephen King novel, but on the other hand I thought that it was quite cheesy and came nowhere near to being as good as the book.The acting coming from James Caan is okay, and the acting coming from Kathy Bates is amazing.One of the things that I like about Misery is the fact that the whole movie is not based just on the book. That is something that I really like to see in movies based on books. Misery is a good film, but it lacks a lot of things, such as the ability to be scary. Misery tries to be scary but it is just not scary at all, I don't think that I came even remotely close once during the entire film. It also lacks the ability to express Paul Sheldon as a lively character. In the book, Paul Sheldon appears to be thoughtful and lively, but in the film he mostly appears to be boring and dull.In the end, I do not think that this is Rob Reiner's best film. He has definitely directed better films than Misery like A Few Good Men, but I do think that it is okay. In my opinion, this was a very big missed opportunity for Rob Reiner. I think that he had the chance to turn Stephen King's novel Misery into a very scary movie. But that is not what he did. Misery is a good film, but unfortunately it is nothing more than that.

Wow. Maybe I'm biased, but first of all, I have loved Stephen King since adolescence. Born in 1976 (and having a father completely enamored by everything Stephen King had ever written) and seeing this in my teens was amazing. Scary. Now that I've finally watched this movie again (43😨) I am in one word... Terrified. It's absolute brilliance. I know the background, have followed all of SK's works, and can say that this, my dear friends, is nothing short of his best story. Enjoy

The movie "Misery," based on the book by Stephen King, is a movie that keeps you on the edge of your seat the whole time! It starts off with a famous writer getting into a car accident. He ends up at the home of his "number one fan." The fan, Annie Wilks, played by Kathy Bates, is such a troubled woman, and the way she acts towards Paul makes us realize our obsessions, and what we would do to get them. Though crazy and psychotic, Annie reminds us of what we truly are, obsessive creatures.Leaving Paul in the bedroom also adds suspense. Throughout the whole time he is there, you start to wonder what is really outside of those walls. Annie Wilks' house is charming and sophisticated, which is ironic in a way, and that is what makes her so lovable.Even though her beliefs are totally out of whack, they make you hate her, but love her at the same time.Annie's unusual beliefs and Paul's struggle to survive make this movie a great thriller for those who can't stand ghosts and monsters. I give it a 9 out of 10!

By its new story it gives the audience a chance to feel that there are still several untold stories that can be illustrated in an artistic way.Brilliant film script of the movie which is based on a novel is just a piece of valuable jewellery.I loved every moment of the movie...the point which makes the film unique is its great directing and awesome performing of the actors and actresses .The movie gave me different feelings of love,sadness,pain,excitement and revenge.A movie wouldn't be able to do such a thing with its viewers unless it is perfect in all aspects.I do recommend watching this movie to whomever wants a brilliant drama thriller with a bit of mysterious atmosphere till the middle of it.

Review title: The best movie by Stephen King ever!!!
Review_body: This is one of the best movies I've ever seen. It has everything; Drama, horror, suspense. If this were real life and I was Paul Sheldon, I'd be so freaked out, it's not like he wasn't. It's just I'd be a little more freaked out, because I'm younger. The movie scared me. When Annie Wilks hit Paul with the sludge hammer, I turned around and limped out into the kitchen that's how bad it hurt.When Paul finds the pin and tells her to go get paper for him, I thought he was really going to get out! I was cheering for him to get out and... the phone has nothing in it! It's nothing... there are no wires in it or anything, and then in the same scene when he gets to the kitchen and finds out it's locked... that part was scary. The expression on his face when he heard the car coming up the driveway... I was screaming at the TV "Get back there, Hurry!" The final scene when Paul burns his book, I was scared and happy for him. But when they were fighting, I think that was the best scene in the entire movie. I Really loved that movie and I'd give it a 1,000,000 out of 10 but that's not a rating so I went with 10/10.

It did not do justice to the novel, Misery, by Stephen King.  The story line was just to far away for it to be enjoyable.  I sat there in horror watching what the writers, directors, actors, and everybody else involved did to massacre such a good book.  It was wrong.

God Of Modern Horror,Stephen King wrote another intriguing,genuine and brilliant thing. And when you add on top of it fantastic directing, marvelous photography, cute and gorgeus James Caan and........ Breathtaking,wild and beautiful Kathy Bates you've got one of the masterpieces of modern horror. As my favourite film of all the time is another Stephen King's novel " The Shining",next to it is "Misery". Stephen King always cheated on human with some partial combinations of evil,suspense,deaths and warmth in the middle of. In almost every King's work we have some very warm characters of which you have more creeps than with the villains. This divine piece of dramatic,claustrophobic riding thriller will always stay in anals of cinematography as perfect work in both ways: Telling the story and presenting the true horror that actually exists in this poor,climacteric planet

This film is one of the best ever! It is intelligent and scary and just plain GOOD!!! I think the only tiny letdown is at the end, because the film seems to stop taking itself seriously which is usually a good thing, but it didnt really work well in this case. That didn't wreck a great movie, though, and Kathy Bates totally deserved the Oscar she won. The way she played Annie definately rates up there with Tony Perkins and Norman Bates. Just superb performances by everyone, especially Kathy Bates and James Caan. Watch it and Love it!

Review title: The production makes it great; The stars make it extraordinary!
Review_body: Misery is a truly deep and disturbing film. I've read the book and, whilst being a true wonder, is an almost different experience from this film. Kathy Bates' Annie will undoubtedly haunt your nights in bed. The cinematography is eye-popping and Bill Goldman's script is a flawless adaptation of King's greatness. Rob Reiner turns in a fine directing job. But it's the story that hooks you. A popular romance novel crashes and is rescued by his #1 fan. Except she turms out to be really crazy. And that's not even the 1/2 of it. But all in all you are amazed by the two performances. This one must been seen to loved."Annie, whatever it is you're thinking about doing...please don't do it."
I created my IMDb account just to rate this masterpiece, do your self a favor and watch it.

7.7? i give it 10 this is one of the sickest and and most interesting films i've had the pleasure to watch. Annie Wilkes must be one of the best thought out, deranged characters ever concocted by a writer and the actor who plays her is just fantastic. I saw the trailer and could only think: "I have to see this", i did and there was no disappointment whatsoever. I love the scene where she breaks his legs, that made me twitch and my friends turned away. I also love the scene where the police officers are investigating in the snow and the camera moves to a car going by and its Annie smiling. She's ****ing crazy. Great film. Buy or rent

Writer Paul Sheldon finishes the last book in his 'Misery' series. Soon after, he loses control of his car during a snowstorm and sustains crippling injuries. He is found and looked after by nurse Annie Wilkes, his "number one" fan.Terrific film. 10/10

Review title: Will keep you on the edge of your seat!
Review_body: This film was full of suspense and unnerved the viewer to see such a situation unfold. Kathy Bates' performance was chilling and truly unsettling. Caan played the role of a suffering, yet plotting man trapped by a deranged woman incredibly well. Definitely recommend this thriller!

This movie absolutely scared the daylights out of me. No horror movie has ever scared me nearly as much as Misery did.I guess because the fact there are insane fans out there. I mean just look at John Lennon or Selena. They were both killed by their fans. Watching this frightens you and makes any average joe thankful he does not have a "fanbase."What makes this movie scary is the fact it could actually happen.It doesn't have crap like a psycho murder who can't die, or some ghost/monster like creature.Kathy Bates does a great job with her role. I recommend this movie to anyone who wants a real scare.

Annie Wilkes is one of the best villians in the history of horror. I think the book is much better than the movie, but I have nothing to say about Kathy Bates in this movie. Outstanding. An Oscar couldn't be more well-deserved than this one.

Review title: Suspense and tension right up there with Hitchcock
Review_body: This is great movie to watch. Kathy Bates earned a well deserved Oscar for her portrayal of the psychotic Annie Wilkes. The suspense and tension build to unbelievable highs. I know a few people who never made it through the hobbling scene - when Kathy Bates picked up the sledge hammer, they knew what was coming and just couldn't stand to watch it. See the "restored" wide-screen version on DVD - you won't be disappointed.

An excellent film of kidnapture with very little characters.From Steven King and Rob Reiner (Stand By Me,This Is Spinal Tap)this films makes you wonder,are there people like this?The story revolves around a character named Annie Wilkes,a fan of a writer named Paul Sheldon.Paul gets hurt in a car crash and is rescued by Annie.The problem is Annie is obsessed,and psycho!When she is disappointed from Paul's latest book after he kills off her favorite character.So,she makes him write a new book for her.The film is a bit dated but anyone should be pleased by watching this film.Believe me,Annie is one psycho b*tch.

From the beginning to the end, the movie showcases a well crafted and tight script. The lead woman character...what a brilliant performance!! Another movie "Run" (2020) similar to this movie is also a great watch!!

Go read the book. The book is so much better than this movie. The movie has scenes that aren't urned. The book is amazing the movie is ok. This movie is only worth watching for Kathy bates. 5 out of 10 go read the book.

Review title: the review of a 14 year old girl
Review_body: I don't watch much thrillers but I just wanted to say that the "thriller" part was perfectly done. From the moment he woke up in the house till the very end I was on the edge of my seat! I don't think there was a boring part at all. Everything that happened needed to happen. And one thing that I think was very good is that Annie, in my eyes, actually looked like a really nice woman. But seriously it was just so perfect that when she got angry she was REALLY creepy but when she was just smiling you could see a nice person even though you knew she wasn't.7.5 for me.

I have watched Misery many times over the past few years and still look away at the sledgehammer/foot scene. Nobody else could have played the role as well as Kathy Bates did and there is something likable about her even after everything. There was something that made you go 'awww' when she died and feel a little bit sympathetic for her. Well....I did anyway! I did think that there were some very atmospheric bits left out of the film that were in the book (even thought it isn't right to compare) such as the soapy, soupy water drinking scene. However the film is very well done and some of the shots where she is in the room with Paul when he is peeing and also the kiss-blowing were made quite sickening after all she did to him. I have also just helped backstage with the stage show of Misery which is more like the book than the film as there are only the main two characters throughout the whole play, but it does always manage to hold the audience and the best speeches such as the 'Rocketman' one and the part where she tells him she doesn't like swearing were included which brought a bit of humour to it. One of Stephen Kings best stories and film adaptations made even better by Kathy Bates.

Kathy Bates is a wonderful actress in this wonderfully simple but scary movie. One successful writer, one crazed fan, bring them together and you get Misery - how far will Annie go to stay with Paul Sheldon?The movie is pretty much as I imagined it from the novel and, OK, the 'hobbling' is different as many people point out, but it still makes you go 'AGGGGGGHooooooww!!!!'Great movie, watch it!

Review title: Quite possibly the greatest horror film of all time.
Review_body: Adapted from the Stephen King novel of the same name, "Misery" is quite simply the type of movie you can watch over and over again and never be bored- it is rare for a film to get the balance between suspense, acting, gore and thrills spot on but "Misery" does this brilliantly and the end result is simply stunning.Misery tells the story of author Paul Sheldon, world renowned for his work on the series of "Misery" books who is involved in a near fatal car accident and awakes some time later in the spare bedroom of his "biggest fan"- Annie Wilkes, played superbly by Kathy Bates. The story details Annie's obsession with Paul and her peculiar schizophrenic personality that, ultimately, results in her believing that she and Paul are madly in love with each other and should die together.A strong plot from the off (although this is down mainly to King, with only a few tweaks) is combined with excellent character development by James Caan and Kathy Bates who play their characters with a thrilling excellency that absorbs the audience's mind in the story and allows us to relate to each and every action the characters make.The direction, the timing, even the music allow the film to grow and within the first half hour a full blown thriller/horror combo is born- this is the type of film that will have you hooked from start to finish, even when very little is actually happening as we are allowed to delve into the minds and personalities of the characters so much- every time Kathy Bates is on screen I am left almost in awe of her presence. A worthy 10/10 and definitely a film to see before you die!

The movie is excellent and Kathy Bates doing her best work. The part with the 2X4 and the sledge hammer still sends shivers down my spine. Review title: Once again a movie fails to deliver....
Review_body: I do so tire of watching a movie based on a novel thinking it will give the latter the attention and care it deserves. The novel was a thousand times better than this pile of garbage. Movie Annie Wilkes was a Stepford wife compared to novel Annie Wilkes and who is this cockadoodie Buster character? Not even in the novel. So much of the plot was wrong and the most horrifying sequences of events were either changed or left out completely. Stick with the novel and don't bother wasting your time.

This is one of the best suspense thrillers released after Hitchcock's death. James Caan gives a genuine performance as the captured author, Paul Sheldon, and because of this - we can really place ourselves in his shoes during certain difficult situations. But the real gem of the whole movie goes to Kathy Bates, who plays the psycho devout ex-nurse Annie Wilkes perfectly. Her performance can makes us laugh one minute, then make us feel very uneasy and scared the next. Annie Wilkes is, my opinion, one of the greatest villains of all time and Kathy Bates made her what she is. I think that this is probably the most simple psychological thrillers ever made - yet it still manages to affect audiences even to this day. 10/10 HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

Review title: I hate Annie Wilkes, in a good way
Review_body: This movie is a good movie, the only reason for this is Kathy Bates. she does a near flawless job of Annie Wilkes Who in the book, i feel, was a very two dimensional character, along with all the characters.this in turn is one of the downfalls of the movie. the fact that the storyline is very basic and most of the characters are two dimensional. Especaily Paul Sheldon. There is no real character development baring Annie.But Annie is what makes this movie. Kathy Bates does a haunting job of Annie, and i can really tell why she won an award for it. The hobbling scene is so creepy i can barley watch it.Even the house is haunting, like when Paul picks up the phone and it is just a shell. there are some downfalls though in addition to the ones i mentioned earlier. James Carn does an okay job of Paul Sheldon but it is just okay. there is little if any music which can be good or bad. I also don't like the ending but i will not ruin that.all in all i think that Misery is a fine movie but has a few flaws when it comes to character and plot development. 7/10

Paul Sheldon, who is famous for his novels he writes, is traveling to New York with his new book in a big snow storm. He crashes his car and is left to die. But, his number one fan, Annie Wilkes, who is known for killing the objects of people for many decades, rescues him from the car wreck. Annie takes him to her house and begins pumping medicine through his body. As the movie goes on, her temper and violence on Paul Sheldon goes up. She gets mad about the swearing in his book, she gets mad and shakes his bed and hits him with a board when she finds out that he killed Misery Chastain in his book. She gets mad when Paul tells her she got the wrong paper. She has also made him burn his new book and start another book the way Annie wants it. But then something happens to Annie. She is depressed and suicidal. She pulls out a gun with no bullets in it and then tells him she might put bullets in it, then leaves. Paul is left all by himself. He decides to go out of his room to get a knife, when he does he finds her scrapbook called Memory Lane which contains her over the decades where she has killed people and found behind bars. Paul is astonished and returns back to his room into his bed. The rain and thunder is able to be heard outside. After a couple of hours Annie returns then hobbles him. At the end Paul finally kills Annie and then escapes

i really liked this film although it was a bit one-dimensional. both Kathy Bates and James Caan were good at acting the story but i don't think that the story itself flowed with any realism, it wasn't a film you could get lost in. the characters seemed to lack depth and their motivations are a bit vague. in the book the fact of Annie's charges of murder is never even touched upon in the film. this sort of explanation would have cleared u a lot of questions that i had after watching the film, because frankly i thought that Annie's sudden change from nice-as-pie nurse to total psychopath was a bit random!!!! however, this was one of the better adaptations from the great Mr King's novels, but i have resigned myself to the fact that if you want a good scare the best thing to do is read the book rather than watch the film.

There are very few flaws in this film. As horror films go it eats most others alive.Paul Sheldon (James Caan) is an author, most notably for his 'Misery' series. During a blizzard his car goes off the road and crashes. He is 'rescued' by Annie Wilkes (Cathy Bates), who happens to be his number 1 fan, and nursed back to health. Soon it becomes apparent that Annie is unstable and obsessed with Paul, and Paul finds himself crippled, drugged and unable to leave.This is a truly creepy film as it contains a large amount of realism, both in the scenario and the characters, and a particular scene that will make even the hardest person cringe.Tension and suspense combined with terrific, convincing performances make a true horror film, and one much more disturbing than screaming teens, 2D characters and CGI limbs flying. A true masterpiece of cinema. *****

Review title: A perfect movie except for a pretty big plot hole...
Review_body: I am a huge fan of James Caan from the Godfather and the TV show Las Vegas. So of course I'm gonna love this movie. The first time I saw it I couldn't believe how good it was. I do have a rather important question about the plot though... The sheriff finds clues about where James caan is by reading the Misery books and in a small passage there is a reference to court and justice and these phrases match those of Cathy Bates' child murder case in the newspaper. I don't know how that could have happened because James Caan was held hostage the whole time and didn't publish any books while he was at her house... Please help me figure out what happened there..

It is also unusual to see James Caan as a victim in this movie cause he used then at that time to play bad fellas.Mrs Bates undoubtly was to won this Oscar (best female performance)and in my opinion Rob Reiner directed one of the best adaptation of a Stephen King 's novel as well as Stanley Kubrick did with Shining

As a big Stephen King fan I would just have to say that the movie based upon King's novel was extremely well acted.  The could have found better actors to play the 2 starring roles.  Kathy Bates was the perfect match for Annie Wilkes, the deranged fan of Paul Sheldon (played by James Caan).  Kathy Bates more then deserved the award she received for her portrayal of Annie Wilkes and Caan's performance as Sheldon was nothing short of wonderful. I'm sorry if I sound like a critic but I absoultely loved the movie.  You know how people often say the books are always better than the movie? Well, this movie to me is as good as the book.

"Misery" is one of the best adaptations of a Stephen King novel that I've seen. The other was "Salem's Lot".I saw the movie before I read the book, and the book wasn't confusing, which it usually seems to be with King if you see the movie first. This movie holds true to the book very well. There are some slight differences, and I think the book goes much deeper into Annie's psychosis, which I enjoyed more, but these things don't detract from the general quality of the movie. I really enjoyed this film a lot, because Kathy Bates just STEALS the show.Solid 8.

Misery, is a thriller movie about an Paul Sheldon played by James Caan, an author of a fictional books called 'Misery' who is abuducted by Annie (Kathy Bates) after a car crash, his "No.1 fan." At first, she is nice and caring in his healing from several fractures on his leg rendering him immobile, but you begin to get glimpses of her dark side as the film moves on that keeps her unpredictable and makes you hate her. Having seen her dark, gritty side, you are left to sympathize with him.The scenes where he schemes to escape from her is gripping and tense. You desparately want him to escape this monster. The movie rarely has jumpscares but manages to keep you guessing and scared. It is also well written. Every detail in the movie is well tied together and has a consitent plot!

I'm going to keep this short & sweet. Misery is a extremely dark and twisted film based around Annie Wilkes (Kathy Bates) obsession with her favourite writer. If you have read the book and are expecting it to be as graphic and gory , you may be a tad disappointed as it has been toned down a bit. However it does contain one scene that is quite disgusting but i would have hoped that they stuck to the book's shocking graphicness(is that a word :S). Finally ... GO WATCH IT ! ITS GREAT !

This movie is one of the most bone chilling movies I have every seen! It features Kathy Bates as a deranged fan and James Caan as a famous writer. Everything in life is alright for Paul Sheldon(Caan) until he crashes his car and wakes up inside the house of his number one fan, Annie Wilkes(Bates). Annie Wilkes soon shows Sheldon how much she really loves him and his number one bestseller and the main character(Misery). I highly recommend watching Misery if you like anything by Stephen King and anything with a huge element of suspense. You will watch as Paul Sheldon fights for his life inside the house of one who says she "loves" him. You will also watch as a detective tries tirelessly to find Sheldon before something worse can happen to him. You will watch one of the most suspenseful tales by King on screen. Enjoy!

I am not a Steven King fan and have never particularly enjoyed his brand of "horror". And while I don't think this movie is as good as many of the other people who have commented, I do think it deserves some attention, especially for those like myself who appreciate the comic effect that some filmmakers bring the the horror genre. Even though Kathy Bates definitely portrays a very scary woman, this movie (unlike "The Shining" for example) is also supposed to be FUNNY. Cann's rolling eyes and his good-bad overacting when he is trying to appease Bates' deranged character is undeniably comic. Judging from how rare it is, it must be difficult to balance dramatic tension with doses of humor, and Rob Reiner has pulled it off with unusual grace. Unlike B grade horror movies which are so bad that some consider them funny, this movie makes people laugh on purpose, and in so doing, is a good specimen of a very particular genre - long live the 'Horror Comedy'!

Yes, I do think it's the best thriller I've ever seen in my life so far. Full of suspense since the beginning, the movie (based on -I think- the best novel by Stephen King) is not actually the very same of the book. Some of you may think that is not good at all, but you have to think that it's not simple to bring on the screen the emotions and atmospheres of the book, for it's extremely difficult emotionally. But the final result of the movie, although the plot is not so book-alike, anyway, is excellent. Paul Sheldon, played by James Caan, is portrayed first as a strong person (he is a chain-smoker, he drinks) but since his life is in Annie's hands, you understand how his life turns to depend on someone else, and how weak he actually is. Annie Wilkes, played by a terrific Katie Bates (Oscar-winner as Best Actress for this movie), is a complex character, who seems totally normal at the beginning, but since she figures out that Paul (her favorite writer) whom she hosted at her place to take care of after the car crash, had decided to kill her favorite novel-heroine (Misery), she becomes crazy and what was supposed to be a rehabilitation for Paul, becomes a horrible torture. But despite of all the terrible things happening to him, he don't lose his nerve and holds on to the end, trying to escape that horrible place. The final fight is the best part in the movie, in my opinion: how Paul manages to kill Annie with the type-writer, is totally astounding. It all happens on the ground, for both of them are unable to use their own legs. But the very best aspect of the movie is that it's mainly placed in Paul's bedroom: the movie, in my opinion, becomes some kind of "Panic Room" (with Jodie Foster), because it also takes place in a small room. I hope I helped you. Enjoy this title!

That ight i went to my local Blcokbuster and rented it and HOLY COW It was good.Paul sheldon, the famous novelist of the questionably historical "Misery" books, gets into a car crash in the middle of the winter.  The one who helps him get back to help is Aniie Wilkes, his #1 fan.  He grows dependant on Annie and gets addicited to the drug known as Novril which is actually dope which helps the pain go away. When she learns that Misery is killed in his latest book, she demands Paul to write her (and only her) a book about Misery's return.  A very haunting performence by Kathy Bates.
