Review title: For all lovers of the movie, the book is a must-read. Actually the book is a must-read no matter what.
Review_body: Everyone who has seen this movie and enjoyed it (or who ever plans to see it) should read the book. The book is amazing. Stephen King is an incredibly talented, descriptive novelist, and Misery is one of his best works. Also, reading the book first gives you a more in-depth understanding of the horror of the movie. Both are bone-chilling, but the book is horrifying, psychologically scarring, and nightmare-inducing; needless to say it is one of my favorite books in the world. Plus, it's kind of cheap and lazy to see a movie based on a book and not read the book as well. So, read Misery everybody. Satisfaction guaranteed.

So, I came across "Misery" randomly on TV. I had heard of it because it's the movie that apparently made Kathy Bates' career, so I figured I'd watch it, "What the heck?" (I should tell you I really don't do well with horror movies.) At any rate, this movie has burned certain images into my brain for all time. If you've seen it, you probably know exactly which ones I'm talking about: the ones they should have edited on daytime TV. It's unbelievably freaky, because Annie (Bates) seems so normal until it gets into the movie. It's completely well acted on all sides. The casting is amazing, and I was horrified enough to never want to sit through it again. (I know that sounds funny: "It was fabulous, but I never want to see it again!" But I don't do gruesome well....)

Another film adaptation from a Stephen King novel at first got me puffing out my cheeks with the expression "Oh no, not another B style film." as his novels are superb but are not done there full justice by some film directors. At times I got the same feeling of exasperation(on occasion) apart from one stand out saving grace; the performance of Kathy Bates. I can safely say I have never before been so drawn into a character, the execution of the character is mesmerising but most importantly; believable. It's Bates performance which keeps you stuck to your seat with suspense, anxiety and anticipation even to those who have read the novel beforehand. Generally the film has good pace, always keeps you interested if not fully immersed by Bates. On the other hand I still felt it had a 'B-movie' feel to it; background music, choreography, James Caan's performance (at times). Which unfortunately, I felt was like Usain Bolt running on an uneven track; meaning the balance just didn't feel comfortable and too difficult to ignore. However Kathy Bates performance alone should without doubt bring you back to watch it for a second (even maybe third) time. An Oscar worthy showing from an actress in a not so bad setting. Well worth the watch!

Review title: A magnificent Kathy Bates (Contains minor spoilers)
Review_body: Famous writer Paul Sheldon crashes his car on a snowy road in Colorado. He is badly injured and eventually rescued by his number one fan, at least according to her, Annie Wilkes. Instead of being taken to a hospital Annie brings Paul to her home, because "the roads to the inner city are closed". At first, Paul is very grateful but when he realizes that Annie will never let him go he starts to feel a bit anxious. A week or two before he crashed his car he had just had his latest book about Misery published, where in the end, Misery dies giving birth to a child. When Annie has finished reading Misery's Child, and reaches the big conclusion, she gets furious and forces Paul to write a new book where Misery instead survives.Paul Sheldon was played by the Godfather hero James Caan, and Kathy Bates portrayed the somewhat unstable Annie Wilkes, which for her acting she later received an Oscar. I think the movie was very well-done and the actors were all of them very convincing. Especially Kathy Bates was magnificent in the role of Annie Wilkes. There are many scenes where Annie seems to be a sweet woman, for example when she listens to Liberace or whenever she is in a good mood. Kathy Bates really builds up sympathy for her character. As a viewer, I actually cared for both Annie and Paul. I wanted it to work out just fine for both of them. For example when the sheriff was at Annie's house looking for Paul, I did not want the sheriff to find him.If I had to rate this movie, I would put it somewhere between average and good, that is to say, I liked it.

Generally, I try to make it a habit to read the book before I see the movie. I managed to do this this with Misery. This movie is not even comparable to the book. Although Kathy Bates gives a stunning(and Oscarwinning) performance in her role as Annie Wilkes, the movie lacks what made the book as terrifying and suspenseful as it was. Misery as a book was more a psychological thriller than a "cringe as you watch the blood fly" thriller. What I mean is is that the book really got into the mind of Paul Sheldon. It gave you a sense of the loneliness, pain, fear he felt as the story unfolded. The movie version failed to bring the psychological terror that the book had provided. This happened for two reasons. First, James Caan, who portrays Paul Sheldon, is really a second-rate actor. It is a weak performance, and it draws away from the drama of the movie. Second is that a movie format would not allow for Paul to have thought out loud, or for his thoughts to have been projected to the audience. EVERYBODY I KNOW WHO LOVES THIS MOVIE HAS NOT READ THE BOOK. If you have not seen this movie READ THE BOOK and then watch the movie. If you have seen the movie and not read the book, READ THE BOOK then watch the movie again. I'm sure you will agree with me.

I love Stephen King's book and his movies and this is one of my all-time favorite Stephen King movies of all time! Kathy Bates, and James Caan do very well together. I you haven't seen this movie go buy it, don't rent, because you'll want to watch more than once. There is a very good story line for the movie, and it is a very suspenseful movie as well. Typical of Mr. King of course all of his works are masterpieces. Stephen King Is the GREATEST AUTHOR OF ALL TIME!If you are just getting into Stephen King's movies I also recommend Riding the Bullet, It, Stand by Me, and of course Pet Semetary. Don't get me wrong Mr. King has many great movies but those are just some of my personal favorites.

Review title: Misery, the play, is coming to Connecticut!!!
Review_body: For those of you who love the book and the movie - there is also a play version of King's Misery. It was originally on-stage in London and starred Sharon Gless (Cagney and Lacey) as Annie. The play opens on Friday, February 24, 2006 and will run for three weeks, closing March 12. It's being produced in Manchester, CT at the historic Cheney Hall (Connecticut's oldest theater), by the Little Theatre of Manchester. You can get tickets by calling (860)647-9824. Tickets are around $20. Mention that you saw the announcement on IMDb. Warning: The play is based on the book - not the movie. It's just a two person show - just Paul and Annie to the end. It's a lot more "oogy"! Axe and all!

The movie Misery made in 1990 originated from book written book written by Stephen King in 1987. This movie is about Paul Sheldon, a very famous author who happens to have a series of unfortunate events happen to him. The events start with him driving in a bad snowstorm and getting into a car crash after leaving a meeting with one of his associates about his soon to be released book to his series. Unconscious he is stuck there on the side of the road until some help finally comes along, and when help finally arrives it turns out to be his "number one fan" Annie Wilkes, a former nurse. She then takes him to her home, out in the middle of nowhere, away from the city and keeps him there to try to help nurse him back to health until she could get him to a hospital. As he regains consciousness she goes on to tell him what happened to him and why he was at her house. Everything seemed to be fine until they began to talk about the new book that he had written. Annie was very interested in knowing what Paul had written in the next book and what would happen to her favorite character. He allows her to read the book and that is when everything went down hill for Paul. She finds out that in the end of the book he writes it to where her favorite character dies giving birth to her child, and Annie was not happy about this at all. Annie couldn't seem to differentiate the book world from the reality world, so she gets very upset and begins to drug him so that he will rewrite the book to where that character lives. Once Paul figures out that this woman is completely crazy he starts to just go along with it so that he wouldn't get hurt. He was already in a wheelchair because his legs had been hurt in the crash. Once he was well enough she began leaving him in the house by himself and he thought it might be a good idea to explore the house a little to try to find a way to get away from her. However; she ends up finding out and drugging him to drag him back to the room. The next day she "punishes him" for leaving the room by putting a block of wood between his ankles and hitting them with mallets to break his ankles. If his ankles were broken he would be in too much pain to think about getting out. Back around Paul's home they begin to notice that he is missing and become worried. Some how they end up noticing the supplies that Annie is picking up from the store and get suspicious. One of the older policemen go out to her house to check things out and Paul notices someone is there and starts to make noise to get their attention. Annie realizes that she could get caught and ends up killing the policemen. Later on in the movie she ends up getting a gun with two bullets, one for Paul and one for her. She tells him that she is doing it only because she loves him. Later on him and Annie get into an altercation that leads to him hitting her in the head with something. She later dies and other help ends up coming because the policeman was missing too long. Once he gets rescued he ends up publishing his book; however, he has nightmares about Annie and the things she had done to him. As a result of the things she had done to him he had trouble writing, became an alcoholic, and had withdrawals from all the drugs she had given him. This is a very good, thought out, and intriguing novel that makes you never want to put it down. The visuals and details that are given in this book are an absolute delight to read and imagine. I really enjoyed the fact that the details did not get lost in translation from the book to the movie. I appreciated the fact that they stayed so very true to the book, changing as little as possible. It could be argued that the book is always better than the movie, but this movie was fairly close to being just as good as the book. The producers of the movie did a fantastic job of making the story line identical to the book. Yes, some things did get tweaked and changed a little. Annie's description in the book was a lot more horrible in the book, but in the movie she was still pretty gross. Another thing the producers tweaked was the part in the movie where she breaks his ankles. The vivid description in the book might have been a little too much to put in the movie because it was so gruesome, but I still think of that as one of my favorite scenes in the movie. This movie is an emotional roller-coaster that will have you emotions from one end of the spectrum to the other. Me being an avid reader I would recommend watching even if you have read the book. You won't be disappointed.

In the midst of his writing career Stephen King wrote the book "Misery", about a writer named Paul Sheldon who is in a car wreck and is saved by Annie Wilks, who keeps him as her prisoner forcing him to write another book. And in 1990 Rob Reiner directed the movie adaptation and does an outstanding job of making King's book come to life. The film follows Paul Sheldon (played by James Caan, with the role of Annie played by Kathy Bates) as he completes his latest book he is driving home when he is in a car accident and is saved by Annie. Annie claims she is Paul's biggest fan and throughout the film we start to believe her. When Paul first comes to he is in the home of Annie she has nursed him back to health and at first it just seems she is a loving and caring person. She is overly obsessed with Paul's Misery books, a collection of romance novels that Paul is famous for. But after she reads the ending of his latest one, she is furious to learn that Paul has killed Misery. She then later tells Paul that not one person knows where she is she has informed nobody that he is in her house. The local police chief sets out to find Paul. All the meanwhile when Annie is out Paul is making trips to and from his room obtaining a knife and several pain killers. Annie is not please pleased with Paul's new non-Misery novel and forces him to burn it. She then buys him a typewriter and forces him to bring Misery back and write a new Misery book. He has no choice but to start writing. He writes through the whole winter lifting up the 10 pound typewriter to gain his strength back. But when Annie discovers that Paul has been out the punishment is harsh. She places a block of wood on his ankles and breaks both of them with a sledgehammer, creating one of the most skin crawling shots in history. Paul tries many times to escape but always ends up failing, such as drugging Annie's wine with the saved up pain pills. We also find out that Anni was accused of murdering newborns in her time working at the hospital. In the movies finale the Sheriff finds Paul in Annie's house, however Annie does not take kindly to this and kills him. She says they both must die in order to bring misery back to the world. Paul goes along with this saying he must first finish the novel. In the very last scene of the movie Paul has finished the book and Annie gathers a gun with 2 bullets and 2 glasses of wine. Right before their suicide and toast to misery, before Annie gets to read the final chapter and find out the answer to everything she wanted to Know about Misery all these years Paul burns the book right in front of her. Diving to save the book Paul strikes her over the head with the typewriter and shoves the burning pages in her mouth. This final fight scene is more memorable than any kung-fu action movie out there. Going from a romantic comedy like "When Harry Met Sally" to a full blown horror flick like "Misery". Reiner does a fine job winning himself and the actors some Oscars for the film. Misery was James Caan's last truly good film, and Kathy Bates delivers one of the scariest performances in horror movie history surpassing Jason, and Freddy. In a nutshell Misery remains one of the scariest movies of all time.

A best-selling novelist called Paul Sheldon is on his way home after completing his latest book, when he crashes his car in a blizzard. Paul is injured, but he is fortunately rescued by a nurse called Annie Wilkes who tends to be his 'number one fan' and takes Paul to her house in the mountains without telling it to anyone. While others are searching for Paul, Annie's obsession takes a dark turn when she finds out that Paul had killed her favourite character from the novels. As Paul devises plans for escape, Annie grows extremely violent.
